Speaker: Mr MILTON
Title: STANDING COMMITTEE ON
text: La Trobe)-On behalf of the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation, I present the report of the Committee on relocation of naval facilities to Jervis Bay, together with copies of the extracts of the minutes of proceedings. Ordered that the report be printed.

Speaker: Mr MILTON
Title: STANDING COMMITTEE ON
text: by leave-This report is the result of inquiries which the Committee decided to conduct as a consequence of a statement by the Minister for Defence ( Mr Beazley) and a joint statement in late 1985 by the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) and the Premier of New South Wales on proposals to relocate naval facilities from Sydney. It was stated that the Royal Australian Navy armament depot at Newington would be relocated to Jervis Bay and a study would be conducted for the re-establishment of a base for the fleet, submarines, mine countermeasure vessels and patrol boats. Our concern was to make sure all the proper planning and environmental considerations were given due weight in the Government's decision. While no public hearings were held, the Committee conducted inspections of the Jervis Bay area and naval establishments in Sydney and at HMAS Stirling in Western Australia and discussions were held with defence personnel, local councils, conservation organisations, Aboriginal groups and government departments. The Committee in the Twenty-ninth Parliament presented a report in 1975 on development pressures on Jervis Bay and recommended that any proposal to develop naval facilities be subjected to an environmental impact statement, and if it could be demonstrated that a more suitable alternative site exists, the Government should not agree to the proposal. The present Committee agrees with this recommendation. Jervis Bay is at present relatively free of major development and is highly regarded as a natural environment with scenic beauty, important contax. servation and recreation sites of scientific and archaeological significance. There is also a number of Aboriginal sacred sites about which concern was expressed. The Committee was very mindful of the concerns regarding the possible despoliation of these features if development is allowed and this was of uppermost importance in deliberations on the proposals. Present naval facilities in the area, namely, the Naval College HMAS Creswell and the bombardment range on Beecroft Peninsula, have been established for many years, have blended in with the environment and have been accepted by the local residents. However, there is some opposition to further development because of the possible detrimental impact on the environment. The relocation of the armament depot from Newington is essential because of the inappropriateness and inefficiency of the present site. The Committee believes that it does not necessarily mean that relocation should be to Jervis Bay, nor is the Committee convinced that future technological developments of munitions storage have been taken into account. In the view of the Committee, further studies are required into stores and ordnance facilities, with other sites being examined, before any final decision should be reached. A decision about the armament depot should not lock the Navy into a decision about the relocation of the fleet base. It should be noted that in his report on the Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities tabled EmptyHere Dibb found that, while there are some potential operational benefits for the Navy in the use of Jervis Bay, an accelerated move out of Sydney Harbour would not be justified by any pressing strategic imperative. The Navy advised that, subject to the completion of a modernisation program, the fleet base in Port Jackson would be capable of adequately accommodating a fleet of the present size into the twenty-first century. The location of an operational base so near to the centre of a large modern city may pose environmental and strategic problems, particularly in wartime, but there does not appear to be any urgent need to relocate major fleet elements to Jervis Bay. The results of a study established by the Minister for Defence to exaIIline the possible re-establishment to Jervis Bay of the fleet facilities at Garden Island, the submarine base and the patrol boat and mine warfare base are expected in the near future. The Government is then expected to decide whether relocation to the Bay should be pursued further. The Committee is concerned that this study will not be subject to public review, that it is based on the assumption that relocation will proceed and that Jervis Bay is the only possible location. This assumption may well turn out to be correct, but it does not appear to have been subject to detailed investigation within the Navy. The Committee understands that the study now nearing completion is very limited and is being carried out by two or three officers based in Canberra. Clearly, a matter of such vital strategic importance deserves much greater attention. The Committee's main concern is that the Department of Defence is proceeding with an EIS on the Jervis Bay site before it has demonstrated whether the relocation proposals are necessary or that the bay is the best site. No evidence was given to the Committee to show that a comprehensive planning study of facility requirements or of alternative locations has been undertaken. The Committee considers that resources should not be committed to an EIS until public comment has been sought or the report of the Department's study has been reviewed. An EIS then should only be prepared when a case for relocation and reasons for the selection of the preferred site have been presented. Consideration of the Dibb report and decisions on the submarine and mine countermeasures facilities should also be finalised before the EIS is commenced. All honourable members will be aware of the controversy relating to the recent Army land acquisition proposals. I am sure that the Senate committee could reach similar conclusions about the Navy proposal. There appears to be no urgent need to relocate the fleet, especially as Garden Island and HMAS Waterhen are being upgraded and some submarines are to be stationed in Western Australia. The Committee recommends that the EIS on Jervis Bay be undertaken only when a comprehensive planning study and public review of naval requirements and alternative sites demonstrates that relocation to the bay is necessary and any development be in the context of the overall proposal for fleet facilities around Australia. The Committee would support further development at Jervis Bay only if it was shown to be completely necessary, there were no other suitable sites and if environmental impacts were minimal. The need to protect the environment is of vital importance. I would like to express the Committee's appreciation of the assistance given by the Department of Defence and the Royal Australian Navy. Their briefings and discussions were both frank and full. We would also like to express our congratulations to the Navy on the attainment of 75 years of meritable and honourable service to the Australian people. I also thank the Secretariat for its assistance in the inquiry, and in particular Mr Ron Kropp, who was responsible for organising the Committee's inspections and discussions and had prime responsibility for drafting the report. I commend the report to the House.

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: STANDING COMMITTEE ON
text: Macquarie)-by leave-In speaking to this report, I wish to explain why it should be necessary for the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation to state the obvious. As the report notes, the Committee in the Twenty-ninth Parliament reported to Parliament on the development pressures on the Jervis Bay area in October 1975, 11 years ago. The Committee advised Parliament that, although Jervis Bay had the potential for development as a deep water port, its use for such purposes could not be justified in the light of development potential of the existing major ports in New South Wales, and the environmental degradation which would result in the bay. The Committee also found that the Jervis Bay area's primary value as a national resource lies in its development potential for recreation and scientific reference purposes, and large-scale expansion of naval facilities at Jervis Bay would not be compatible with this objective. The Committee recommended that if it could be demonstrated that a more suitable alternative site for such development existed, the Government should not agree to the proposal. It called for the development of a comprehensive Jervis Bay area management plan to be implemented in consultation with the Government of New South Wales and the Shoalhaven Shire Council. Finally, it recommended that any such proposal be subjected to an environmental impact study. A decade after the tabling of that report, there is still no Jervis Bay area management plan, and the development and management plan for the Jervis Bay nature reserve drafted in 1979 is still to be published. Notwithstanding this sorry state of affairs, the Government has decided to relocate the Naval Armament Depot from Newington in New South Wales to Jervis Bay and the Department of Defence, currently examining options for relocation of our Fleet Base, has made its preference for Jervis Bay very clear. This report confirms the conclusions of the 1975 report and the view of the Departmenf of Territories and the National Trust of New South Wales, among others, that the Jervis Bay area is of significant scientific, conservation and recreaoversight tional value. Nevertheless, the Committee has indicated that it would support further development of the Bay area by the Navy where the Navy could prove such development was absolutely necessary. Of particular importance would be evidence that there were no other sites available. This report indicates, however, that thus far no such evidence or proof has been provided to either the public or to this Committee. Indeed, I would like to note briefly the evidence to the contrary which the Committee had before it. Firstly, a 1979 Garden Island modernisation impact statement which favoured Port Jackson over Jervis Bay, provided there were no major fleet expansions or nuclear warships berth requirements; secondly, the findings of the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities this year that, while there are some operational benefits at Jervis Bay, the substantial expenditures of dislocation involved in relocation would not be justified by any pressing strategic imperative; thirdly, the fact that partial fleet relocation to Western Australia in terms of the Government's two-ocean Navy strategy would seem to obviate the need to relocate from Port Jackson. The report indicates that the Committee is of the opinion that the recommendations of the 1975 report are still applicable, particularly large scale expansion of naval facilities would not be compatible with the management of Jervis Bay as a natural area. The report also recommends that any such expansion of naval facilities be subjected to an environmental impact statement. However, environmental impact statements are time and resource consuming and such a statement in this case could cost in excess of $lm. The Committee has therefore been forced to state the obvious-that the Department of Defence should concentrate its efforts on developing a comprehensive and integrated facilities requirements master plan, rather than proceed with an EIS based on the assumption that relocation is necessary and must occur at Jervis Bay. I hope that honourable members will take notice of this report. It should not be necessary for a parliamentary committee to advise a Minister and his or her department that before he or she takes a course of action he or she examine whether it is absolutely necessary and whether alternative options are available. I ask honourable members to note this report because the 1975 report, to which I have referred, also stated the obvious. Yet its obviously necessary, sensible and simple recommendations have been ignored or implemented at a snail's pace. It would seem that the Parliament has been negligent in its of the implementation of the report and therefore of its stewardship of the Jervis Bay area. I hope that its attention to the simple recommendations of this report will put an end to that neglect.

Speaker: Mr CHYNOWETH
Title: STANDING COMMITTEE ON
text: Dunkley)-by leave-I wish to speak briefly about the environmental impact that relocation of naval facilities to Jervis Bay might possibly have on this very beautiful area of Australia. I had never been to Jervis Bay until the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation went there, but I found the waters in the area to be exceptionally crystal clear. It is a magnificent site for any port and any recreational activities that may take place. Some 30 years ago Western Port Bay used to be similar. It had crystal clear water, beautiful seagrass and white, sandy beaches. I can remember swimming near the Cowes Pier when I was a lad and there was seagrass all around it. Since the development of Western Port Bay and the anchoring of thousands of oil tankers there, the waters have been stirred up and there is increased turbidity. The sunlight does not get through and the seagrass no longer grows there. This has affected fish and other forms of marine life which once lived in this area. I know from experience that that water is no longer nice and that clear. I would hate to see that sort of thing happen to Jervis Bay. I have pointed this out to the Royal Australian Navy and I am certain that if there ever were any relocation it would take these factors into account. It is very important that this particularly beautiful part of Australia be preserved for future generations. The Committee also went to Newington in Sydney Harbour. The relocation of the armament base there is a must. Local councils have allowed development right up to the wire around the base and in some places ammunition is stored only 100 metres from a huge glass wall. If an accident occurred and one of these bunkers exploded, havoc would be created in that area. Therefore, this base must be moved. Another matter of concern to me was the destruction of part of the Drummond Drumsticks-a rocky outcrop just off Jervis Bay which has been used for bombing practice over the years. This was drawn to the attention of. t-e Minister for Defence ( Mr Beazley), and It IS being examined. I believe there will be no further use of this particular landmark, which was an aiming area for both the Royal Australian Air Force and the Royal Australian Navy when dropping. their bombs. It is a beautiful area, it should be looked after and we should do all we can to maintain it. I wish to congratulate the Navy on its 75 years of existence. Many people have forgotten that the Royal Australian Navy was established by the Australian Labor Party and I believe that the Government should be proud of that. We were the ones who initiated the RAN and brought it into being.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Title: STANDING COMMITTEE ON
text: New England-Leader of the National Party of Australia)-by leave-The Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation deserves to be commended for the report that it has brought forward, although there are some problems in the character of future naval movements and I wish to alert the Committee to them. I share the general concern about the status of Jervis Bay, which has been described by several members as unique. The waters are crystal clear and the sand has unique characteristics. It really is a quite magnificent part of Australia. However, having said that, I think that it is equally necessary to look at the long term planning of naval facilities around Australia. I say to the Department of Defence that I think it is absolutely essential that it take on board the consequences of the lessons learned from the land acquisition schemes for Army training facilities in New South Wales. There were a number of very serious and adverse consequences for the district, the environment and landholders, some of whom are still waiting to be told that land acquisition will not proceed. For example, the people in Cobar have not been told that their land is no longer required for military purposes, although a report has been brought out saying that the land is no longer suitable, and despite the recommendations of the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities and the nature of the terrain. In my view Jervis Bay is in a somewhat different position. As has been mentioned, there is little doubt that the Newington facility in Sydney Harbour must be transferred soon. If. it is to be transferred, it is necessary to determme the alternative sites to the port of Sydney for a naval facility, particularly for that munition handling facility. In my view Jervis Bay is the preferable location and I suggest that there has been established a criterion which shows that it is an absolute necessity for the facility to be removed and that Jervis Bay is a suitable location, given the naval facilities already there. Secondly, it is no use looking only at the Stirling base in Western Australia and saying that because facilities can be moved there and because some submarines will be there that one can therefore leave HMAS Platypus, the naval submarine facility at Kirribilli there forever. Of all the naval facilities it is'app-rent that when the new generation .of submarines comes into service it will be essential that they be moved to an east coast base somewhere outside the port of Sydney. I suggest that once again Jervis Bay is the most suitable location. Therefore, it is necessary, with both those facilities and whatever future transfers may be necessary, for there to be a long term pl-n brought forward. As I understand th- Committee's report, it is saying that an envIronmental study should be produced once that decision has been taken. It would be very helpful if the Royal Australian Navy were to bring out a long term plan, looking at not only the Jervis Bay facility, but also every other naval facility around Australia and identifying what it believes to be the long term objective for each facility. For example, I suggest that there is reason for some upgrading of the port of Darwi-, where obviously there could at least be a frIgate berth. I believe that the Port Hedland facility should also be looked at. I have always had doubts about its suitability for patrol boats because of the narrowness of the channel, but there does need to be a facility in the north-west of Western Australia. HMAS Stirling, which is outside Fremantle near Garden Island in Western Australia, is magnificent. It can and will be developed. Again, the natural environment, which is absolutely charming, needs to be protected to the maximum. As we move around the coast, a number of other facilities need to be examined. The Navy should be required to produce a long term plan as to how it sees its progressive establishment. Some of the facilities in Sydney, I believe, will be there indefinitely. I believe that the nature of Garden Island, for example, for all the pressure that I know is on it, is such that it should remain for naval purposes. However, there is a problem in the short term. The two instances that I mentioned-that is, the Newington facility and the future east coast submarine base-are such that I see Jervis Bay as the prime alternative site, and I hope that the Committee and the Parliament will lend a sympathetic ear to the Navy's requirements for I believe that the proper development of Jervis Bay for those purposes, taking into account the unique environment and the requirements of the Navy, should facilitate the development that will help the Australian defence forces, protect the natural environment to the maximum and protect the interests of the residents of that part of New South Wales.

Speaker: Mr SHARP
Title: STANDING COMMITTEE ON
text: Gilmore)-by leave-I rise this afternoon to speak to this report because much of the area that will be affected by any possible moves of the Royal Australian Navy to the Jervis Bay area lies within the electorate of Gilmore. Previous speakers have quite accurately described this as a unique and most attractive part of the Australian coastline. All of us, as decent Australian citizens, should be concerned about how this part of the world is likely to be developed. There is no doubt that the Navy has been a good manager of the land that it has held in the Jervis Bay region since about 1914 when HMAS Creswell was established. I do not think people who are prepared to travel into that area and over some of the Navy property could disagree with the fact that the Navy has looked after the area that it holds extraordinarily well. One only has to compare it with other areas that have been developed by either private enterprise or other groups to see that if development is to take place in this part of the world the Navy is a preferred developer because of its track record of good environmental management. A number of speakers today have spoken about some aspects of the development. The honourable members for Dunkley ( Mr Chynoweth) has mentioned that the Westernport Bay area was a lovely part of the world when he was a lad but now it has been unfortunately made not so. The point we have to remember is that that development was undertaken by private enterprise, I understand, with oil tankers and so forth being the main sources of activity there. This is not likely to be the case at Jervis Bay. The Navy will be the main developer and it will be ensuring that any activities that are undertaken will be carried out with the utmost care and responsibility. I am pleased with the recommendations that the Committee has put before the l;Iouse today. I believe it is important that all Australians realise that the Navy is planning its future not just for the next 10 or 20 years but for many, many years ahead. It is important that we all remember that what the Navy is talking about in relation to Jervis Bay will not happen tomorrow; it is talking about it happening in maybe 10, 15 or 20 years. Nothing will happen overnight. I hope that the Navy will give clear evidence to the Committee, the Parliament and the people of Australia that it has investigated other sites and does not look all the time towards Jervis Bay. From informal discussions with Navy personnel in the region I know that they have been looking at upgrading the Navy's presence in the Jervis Bay area for a long, long time, in order to try to meet the future needs of the Navy. I am quite sure that they will be able to give evidence to the Committee, when they are asked, to indicate that they have looked at a number of other sites. I believe that if the moves that the Navy proposes go ahead they will be welcomed by the local people in the Jervis Bay-Shoalhaven district. From speaking to the local council, many business people and members of the community I know that they look forward to the increasing presence of the Navy. There is no doubt that the Navy personnel have been good citizens of the Shoalhaven district. I believe that if the move goes ahead it will be welcomed; it will be a welcome move for Australia's defences and for our Australian Navy. NA

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: PUBLICATIONS COMMITTEE
text: O'Connor) (4.36)-The Income Tax Rates Bill is necessary to implement the Government's new proposals which it puts under the heading of tax reform. I choose to put them under the heading of a money grab. There is no evidence whatsoever that in the reduction of these rates the Australian people will be better off. There is certainly no evidence of reform. I believe that reform is not just change; reform is change for the better. We have seen other examples today of the Government backing and filling and trying to debate its way out of situations. The Australian people now are fed up with the hard sell that is practised by the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) and his Treasurer ( Mr Keating) in matters economic and in matters of taxation; they are looking for the bottom line. Let us look quickly at a couple of the bottom lines that are relevant to this legislation and the Government's tax approach in general. The reality is that in the last Fraser Budget, the only Budget that was inherited by this Governmentit did not inherit the next one, which was only of its own making-the people of Australia were taxed S44,000m. That was the highest total ever taxed in 83 years of government, I might add. In the Budget which has just been introduced and for which this is enabling legislation, we find that the total of taxation raised from the Australian people is $71,000m. That is an increase in just four years of $27,000m, or 61 per cent. What is more, it represents 25.5 per cent of our gross domestic product, compared with the highest ever figure under a Fraser government of 24.6 per cent. If someone thinks 0.9 per cent is not much money, let me say that in terms of GDP one is talking of a situation in which every one per cent represents something like $2,5OOm. It is a huge burden. a period this Government has been ind in one thing and one thing alonethe argument. Its attitude is: Do not be confused by the facts; win at all costs. We had a classic example of it recorded at page 320 of the Hansard of 20 August when the Prime Minister was trying to argue his way out of the clear example of his Government being the highest taxing government in the history of Australia. He said: If we turn to page 358 of Budget Paper No.1, we see that tax as a proportion of GOP in 1981-82 was 24.7 per cent. If we adjust the 25.5 per centthat is this Government's taxationfor 1986-87 for the financing of Medicare, it comes out at 24.6 per cent. I wonder what in the heck he thinks we are on about. How dumb does he think the Australian people are? The Medicare levy is a tax. It is consuming $4,OOOm-plus of Australian taxpayers' money this year. The Prime Minister wants to make adjustments by throwing out part of the tax that he is imposing on Australia through these measures. Let me look at some of the other recent examples of winning the argument. The Treasurer recently could not even tell the Australian taxpayers whether the $200 charge that he is now imposing for taxation appeals would be returned to the taxpayer if that person won the appeal. One would think that he would know that. Only the other day he came into the Parliament to mislead totally the Australian people by saying that only private kilometres had to be recorded in log books. One has only to look at the so-called approved log book and the legislation the Treasurer brought into this Parliament to see that that is not so; that business kilometres have to be recorded. When we asked the Treasurer what percentage of the fringe benefits tax he thought the public sector might pay, compared with the private sector, he told us that he was not a computer and he was not expected to know those sorts of things. Now the Treasurer is running around America trying to play the same sorts of tricks over there. It is disgraceful. The Americans must wonder where that man comes from and what he is on about, because he is prepared to tell them fibs. He has gone over there and boasted that he is such a great Treasurer that he got the deficit down from 5 per cent of gross domestic product to just over one per cent and he criticised the American nation because its deficit is still 5 per cent. The reality is that the highest ever deficit over which the Treasurer has presided is 4.3 per cent, which is a difference of just 0.7 per cent or $2,OOOm. His current Budget deficit is not just over one per cent; it is 1.4 per centanother $1,OOOm miscalculation by the Treasurer. That 1.4 per cent deficit presumes that he will not do the same as last year and overrun his deficit projection by a mere $800m. There have been 33 Budget deficits in Australia and only 11 of them have exceeded $800m, let alone been overrun by $800m. There is every reason to say that the deficit this year will probably be 2 per cent. If we look at the more realistic comparison with America and add in the public sector borrowing requirements, because American State governments do not run the same sorts of borrowing programs as we do in Australia, we are looking at an original figure of 6.8 per cent and a current figure of 4.9 per cent, which is surprisingly like the American figure of 5 per cent. That is the reality, but this Treasurer is all about rhetoric and currently the rhetoric is on tax. We are to be told anything; the Government does not worry too much about explaining the details. Not long ago business was told that it had plenty of money to pay the 3 per cent productivity claim and the superannuation claim associated with that, because business profits had never been higher; but the figure the Treasurer was using was calculated prior to deducting interest rates and taxation. Everyone knows how those two matters have escalated under this Treasurer. Let us look at the reduced taxation scales the Treasurer is offering Australians, which are significant in some respects. The tax free threshold will rise from $4,595 to $5,100. The rate will reduce from 25 per cent to 24 per cent on the small amount of earnings up to $12,600 and on the intervening amount up to $19,500 the rate will reduce from 30 per cent to 29 per cent. The poor people will get only a one per cent cut, remembering that this Government constantly claims that they are the people it represents. For earnings between $19,501 and $28,000 the rate will drop from 46 per cent to 43 per cent and for earnings up to $35,000 it will drop from 48 per cent to 46 per cent. For the very wealthy, those who earn over $35,000-only the top 2 per cent of Australian taxpayers are in that bracket-the rate will drop from 60 per cent to 55 per cent. Let us look at the harsh reality of those magnificent figures. If we look at what an average weekly earner will pay as a percentage of his total earnings, we discover that under the Fraser Government an average weekly earner-a husband with a wife and two children-paid 17.5 per cent of his total earnings in taxation. That is the bottom line; that is what he understandsnot all the fancy figures that have been bandied around by the Treasurer, who will always find some figures to prove something. When all these lovely tax deductions about which the Prime Minister boasts so much are in place, the average weekly earner will be paying 20.5 per cent of his income in taxation, because in that period we have had fiscal drag and inflation and we have pushed him up into the higher brackets. The rate in the bracket in which the average weekly earner will be will not be reduced substantially, so he has been pushed up into a higher bracket. The bottom line is what the average weekly earner has to take home to spend with small business and other people who need his money. As a percentage of his earnings, he will be 3 per cent worse off under this tax than under the Fraser Government. Even the average weekly earner with no dependants will be one per cent of his income worse off-23.4 per cent compared with 22.4 per cent. There are all these new taxes into the bargain. The fringe benefits tax is 'option ACTU' and it is a tax about throwing out the baby with the bath water. Again we have had this program of misinformation. I will give the Acting Treasurer ( Mr Hurford) his due; at least he has read something about it and he was prepared to tackle the problem today. At least he had the figures reasonably right-something about which the Treasurer has no idea whatsoever. Every time the Treasurer and the Prime Minister, as demonstrated today, are asked to speak on matters relating to the detail of the tax-the way in which the tax will affect the ordinary Australian, which is surely what we are on about herethey cannot answer because they do not have the capacity, background or experience to understand. At least the Acting Treasurer has some idea of that, because he used to be an accountant; but he was telling us only half the story today. He made a comparison between the fringe benefits tax and substantiation for people who own their own cars. When he was specifically asked about that, he started throwing around percentages and, when picked up on interjection, he had to admit that under the fringe benefits tax the percentage applies to the price of the vehicle. In the transitional year it is expected that people will be entitled to a benefit of 18 per cent calculated on the original value of the vehicle.

Speaker: Mr TUCKEY
Title: PUBLICATIONS COMMITTEE
text: Whether or not it is generous, it has nothing to do with keeping a log book and substantiating the claim. A business person wishing to claim a tax deduction on a vehicle either will have to keep a log book or will be able to claim only one-third of the operating cost or 12 per cent of the total price of the car. As the questioner today tried to point out, there is certainly some evidence that the benefit is very much to the corporate employee compared with the small businessman, because the corporate employee will be taxed on 24 per cent of the original value of the vehicle, if he opts for the formula; but the owner will be able to claim only 12 per cent of the original cost as a business cost. He will be taxed on 88 per cent and the corporate employee will be taxed on 24 per cent, or down to 6 per cent. There is a vast difference there, as the questioner today tried to point out. The Government has got it wrong again because it is neither fair nor equitable. There are different deals .for one side and the other. I stand here today as the unashamed representative of the small business sector. Those businessmen and I know that the only way in which they can get a fair deal out of this arrangement is to keep the log book with nine entries every day. God save the poor individual who was driving around in his car on the day the Treasurer got up here and, in an attempt to misrepresent the tax, to dress it up in clothes it is not entitled to wear, told businessmen that they could just record the private kilometres. Now we have something called self-assessment, which is all about telling the Commissioner of Taxation anything you like and he will believe you for the time being; he will take it as read until he sends out a field auditor. So, if a person has claimed major deductions against a log book kept as the Treasurer advised, with only private kilometres recorded in it, under the laws introduced by this Government the field auditor would have every right to reject the claim for a deduction. That means that the individual is left without any evidence of his business kilometres, and it is possible that seven years will pass before the individual discovers that he has it wrong. After all, the Commissioner will not tell him. I have in my hand his little booklet entitled 'Income Tax Self Assessment', a properly issued booklet and one of the hundreds that are burdening business. We are told what the old law was. The old arrangement was that the form was lodged with the Commissioner of Taxation and he, on the basis of the information disclosed in the return, confirmed that the taxpayer had correctly applied the law in calculating his or her taxable income and in claiming rebate. On the next page, we move on to the proposed selfassessment system. The passage reads: In its essentials, self-assessment will not involve a big change. Basically it means; The Commissioner need not (and in the main, will not) check the taxpayer's application of the law before issuing a notice of assessment. If the individual listens to 80me of the interpretations of the Treasurer and gets his self-assessment wrong, the Commissioner will not tell him that it is incorrect before issuing the annual assessment. He will accept the taxpayer's word. It should be remembered, however, that the field auditor will be able to knock on the taxpayer's door up to seven years later, and that there are three years in which reassessment can be made on any ground, including the following four, if it is said that the taxpayer has submitted misleading information. If the individual has made a claim that is not within the interpretation of the law, he has misled the Commissioner and is a tax evader. If that has happened, he is one of the horrible people that Government members constantly talk about. This is what the public is up against and this is what the law is doing. The public will not derive any particular benefit from what is being proposed. Instead, people will pay more in taxation, and much more than they did under any conservative or coalition government. That is the reality and that is the bottom line. The list of this Government's broken promises grows by the hour. 'There will be no new capital gains tax', said the Prime Minister in his policy speech. Of course, there now is one. He promised a drop in interest rates. They have gone up. The Prime Minister promised a 3c per litre cut in petrol prices. They have gone up. In November 1984 the Prime Minister said that inflation would be kept under 5 per cent. It is now over 8 per cent. He promised no increase in the Medicare levy and he has put it up 25 per cent. I cannot think of one promise made by the Hawke Government in its mad grab for power that it has actually kept. This is the most dishonest, contemptible government this country has seen-and after Gough that is saying something. When the Minister for Health originally outlined the Medicare proposal to the Australian people, he said: 'It would be funded by a one per cent income tax contribution'. The Government has systematically and intentionally promoted Medicare on the basis of this false assertion. It clearly intended to mislead the public into believing that the one per cent levy would actually fund Medicare. In one of the biggest frauds perpetrated on this country, people were told that as a result of their payment of a one per cent levy they would receive a green-and-gold plastic Medicare card which they could present to their doctor, public hospital out-patient department or public hospital admitting department for health care, which was to be 'free' if the doctor bulk billed. The fact is that the levy has never come close to paying for Medicare, and the gap between the income generated by the levy and the exploding cost of the Medicare program continues to grow. The Government has merely used the levy as an excuse further to increase the tax burden. This highest taxing government that this country has ever seen has now lifted our top tax rate from 60 per cent to 6lt per cent. Let us look more closely at that capacity of the levy to finance the Medicare program. This year's Medicare budget is predicated on the fact that it will cost the Government $4,000m to provide medical and hospital services under Medicare-and how much will the levy raise? It and will raise $1,645m. So the Government has a $2,355m financial credibility gap to fill. Around 23 per cent of our population are entitled to Medicare benefits by virtue of the fact that they are pensioners, unemployed, or in some other way financially disadvantaged. Of course, they pay no levy; their Medicare costs are paid out of general revenue. The levy also does not apply to around 12 per cent of taxpayers because they fall below the income threshold to which the levy applies. Around 40 per cent of all Medicare benefits are paid on behalf of those who pay no levy at all, and of course all these benefits are paid out of general revenue, to which all taxpayers contribute according to their taxable income. The amount raised by the levy does not even cover the medical costs of those who pay the levy because their health costs are also subsidised by general taxes. In other words, they are funded out of general revenue, to which they already contribute by way of the graduated tax system. The majority of Medicare 'expenditure is funded from general revenue, not from the levy. Let me put it another way. As I have said, the Medicare levy will raise $1,645m of the $4,OOOm cost of Medicare, so the levy would have had to be trebled in this Budget to pay for Medicare. It is therefore absolutely arrant nonsense for the Government, the Treasurer ( Mr Keating) or the Minister for Health to claim that Medicare is self-financing. The Medicare program is funded in the main out of general revenue, and the Medicare levy is nothing more than an additional tax. Any financial relationship which the levy may have borne to the rocketing costs of the Medicare program has long since been left on the drawing board of the program's architects. In summary, financing of the Medicare program through the introduction of the levy represents yet another of the financial myths which have characterised the policies of this Government and its glib and confused Treasurer. text: Lowe) (6.1O)-We are dealing with legislation to increase the Medicare levy from one per cent to 1.25 per cent as a Budget measure. In the current financial year the composite rate of the levy will be 1.145 per cent. The legislation will also extend the range of people who do not have to pay the levy. People with larger families who are earning average weekly incomes will not be caught by the levy at all. People with four or five children will not be required to pay the levy because limits have been set to protect families with low incomes, individuals with low incomes or large families with middle incomes. I wish to say a few words about the comments EmptyHere ter) and his unfortunate undertaking to make changes and to dismantle Medicare should the Liberal and National parties ever get back into office. As everyone knows, when the Australian Labor Party came to office in 1983 two million Australians were uninsured. That had enormous implications for health services and those trying to deliver health services, be they public hospitals, general practitioners worrying about uninsured patients, hospitals trying to collect bills, people who through ill health, misadventure or bad luck let their health insurance lapse and suddenly found themselves uninsured. It was a total mess. As the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) pointed out in an answer to a question in the House on 22 September last, if the Liberal Party of Australia philosophy were adopted and people were allowed to opt out of the levy-essentially it is the people at the top end of the levy, the high income earners, who opt out-this would cost $1,6OOm. That would be the cost if a scheme of Medicare were adopted where one could choose whether or not to join. The essential argument for Medicare is that all Australians should have access to medical and hospital facilities. It is a simple and equitable scheme which is financed by a levy on incomes. The levy is not applicable to every person; essentially it applies only to those who earn more than average weekly earnings, especially if they have a large family. It does not apply to certain categories of people, such as veterans, war widows or those who receive certain defence pensions or emoluments. The honourable member for Barker made an unfortunate criticism of the public hospital system, which I feel I must refute. I have spoken to a senior executive officer and other staff of the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital, which is a very large teaching hospital in Sydney with nearly 1,200 beds. Those people explained to me that unfortunately there are waiting lists, but this is entirely due to the nursing shortage, a shortage which particularly affects New South Wales. Approximately 50 per cent of medical admissions come through casualty, and there is no delay in getting a bed for those people who come through casualty. The problem of waiting lists in public hospitals has nothing to do with Medicare at all; it is essentially caused by a shortage of nurses. The Government, in co-operation with State governments, is trying to recruit nurses from overseas to hospitals here and it is also running a program to retrain nurses. At the Concord Repatriation General Hospital in my electorate a very positive scheme for the retraining of nurses has been running for some time. The notion of choice in the levy may sound very good, but it has appalling implications. It is very unfortunate that the Liberal and National parties have made a commitment to prevent ordinary families from being included in bulk billing. If the Opposition ever got into power, it would confine the Medicare scheme to pensionor ers and the very poor. That would be a total negation of the right of choice which families should have. People in my electorate who have children often have to go to a general practitioner or medical centre at weekends and they often select one which bulk bills. People should have the right to approach a general practitioner or medical centre where they know they can be bulk billed. It is contrary to the so-called Liberal philosophy of freedom of choice that families will not have the right to be bulk billed. If a family has a child who is sick-say, a diabetic or an asthmatic-they will not have the right to go to the doctor of their choice and have the doctor bulk bill for them. People are often short of money, particularly at weekends or before pay-day, and they should have the right to be bulk billed. The Hawke Government has pledged that Australians will have the right to approach the doctor of their choice, a doctor who will bulk bill them if they so choose. Unfortunately, the Liberal and National parties are rejecting that proposal, and I feel that it is an attack on families and their rights to security in sickness, to obtain treatment without having to find the funds necessary there and then, or having to make a claim and seek a payment. I made the point earlier that the levy does not apply to large families. A family of six can earn $23,300 and be exempt from the levy. That is well above the average weekly earnings. If a family with six children earns more than that, there is a certain shading in, so that up to nearly $25,000 of net income a large family does not have to pay the full levy. The levy starts at $8,300 for individuals and a single parent or family can earn $13,370 before the levy is paid, then $1,660 is added on to the exemption for each dependent child. So the bigger families have the advantage of not having to pay the levy if they are in the middle income bracket. The other matter on which I want to touch is the implication in the comments of the honourable member for Barker that 40 per cent of Medicare treatments are provided to people who are now not paying the levy. I believe that the philosophy and policy of the Liberal Party is nonsense. The Minister for Health, in reply to a question in the House in September, said that the only way the Liberal Party could implement its policy would be by doubling the levy to 2.5 per cent, as is did in 1976 when it introduced a scheme such as the scheme it is talking about now. The Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Howard) is talking about abolishing the various taxes introduced by the Government and funding everything by cutting back on Medicare. The other horrendous alternative would be that the Liberal-National coalition would cut back on the free medical care provided to pensioners and the disadvantaged. That would be a disgrace. The members of the Opposition go around this nation saying that they will cut back taxes and abolish this and that, but they have not clearly defined how they would finance such cutbacks in taxes. The only alternatives are either that they double the levy to 2.5 per cent or more, or that they cut back on the provision of free medical care to pensioners and the disadvantaged. It would be a tragedy and a travesty that our old people, our pioneers, would not have the right to free medical and hospital treatment which they now have. The honourable member for Baker ( Mr Porter) made a slighting comment about the former Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, which was uncalled for. Mr Whitlam is a great statesman and a great Australian. I support the legislation that is before the House. I believe that Medicare gives Australians a simple and universal health scheme which is easily understood and by which Australians benefit. I believe also that ultimately the nurse shortage in the various public hospitals will be overcome and that many of the complaints about delays and waiting lists will be removed in the fullness of time. There is a cyclical effect with the different intakes and the additional training year that is thrown in, particularly in New South Wales. The standard of care in public hospitals is first rate and I give credit to those who run the hospitals, those who work in them and those who service the poor, the needy and the families of our country. I ask the House to reject the amendment moved by the honourable member for Barker.

text: Corangamite) (6.21)-The Whitlam Government set theÂ· pace for nationalised health care in Australia by introducing Medibank on 1 July 1975, and since that time we have seen major variations of that theme. The Australian Labor Party and the socialist planners have tried to convince the Australian people that a nationalised health scheme would provide cheaper and more efficient health services. All the evidence to date indicates that health services cost more and that the delivery is less effective. The recent Budget decision to increase the Medicare levy by 25 per cent signifies a change in both the attitude of the Government and the background philosophy which supports this socialist myth. When Medicare was first introduced on 1 February 1984, the one per cent levy on personal income provi4ed for the payment of medical benefits, free hospital care and a subsidy to all patients in private hospitals. The change announced in the 1986 Budget increases this levy by 25 per cent and does not guarantee public hospital treatment for all citizens, and with the removal of the private hospital subsidy it ensures that private insurance will rise. The total health budget for Australia in 1986-87 will be $7.3 billion, plus identified health grants to the States of $1.6 billion, making a total of $8.9 billion, which is almost $9 billion for Australian health care. As the Government has been successful in promoting the view that the Medicare program provides free health to all Australians and that the Medicare levy in fact covers this provision, Parliament should look very carefully to the content of this false proposition. The truth behind the health budget and the contribution from the one per cent levy for Medicare is that Medicare in the current Budget will generate $1.6 billion, which is 18 per cent of total health outlays across Australia, both Commonwealth and State. This is a far cry from the perception of taxpayers and their families that their Medicare levy entitles them to free health care from doctors and hospitals. The Government has been quick to claim the credit for a universal health scheme, but is reluctant to take the responsibility for the problems faced by the State health administrations in providing health services. In Victoria, for example, queues grow on a daily basis and currently hospitals have waiting lists of approximately 28,000 persons seeking hospital treatment. In Victoria, with the advent of the Labor Government in 1982 and the introduction of Medicare, the State health system is now in a state of chaos, which clearly indicates that nationalised medicine under Labor governments does not work. The Medicare levy as indicated in the Budget Papers will be increased from 1 December 1986 from one per cent to 1.25 per cent of taxable incomes that exceed certain thresholds. As a result, government revenue will rise from $1.28m in 1985-86 to $1.645 in 1986-87, an increase of 23.2 per cent. This Labor Government has proclaimed loudly its record on tax reform, but on this issue it has increased taxation in a very subtle form, again throwing away one of its major promises-that it would not, in any circumstances, increase the Medicare levy from one per cent. In reality, the increase of the Medicare levy is another form of taxation which is directed to general revenues, but is disguised as a non-tax item. The Treasurer ( Mr Keating) has no hesitation in increasing this levy as a form of increasing government revenue in his efforts to prop up the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) and the profligate spending of his Department. Consistent with its socialist philosophy, the Government has now discriminated against the private sector by removing the hospital bed subsidy for private hospitals as from the August Budget 1986. The Government claims that it will save $129m in a full year because it has removed the $40 a day subsidy for each bed in a private hospital. In reality the Federal Government is saving money by assisting private hospitals, because across Australia the average bed cost in a public hospital is in the order of $240 a day. It is ironic that the Government chose to attack the private hospital system when the public hospital system is in a state of disarray. Daily reports in Victoria indicate major problems with nurses' strikes, hospital budget deficits, lack of financial allocations, long waiting lists and low morale in every quarter. The private health system has managed to complement the public health system in a very effective and efficient way in past years. It should be nourished, not destroyed. The Government has been forced to take some remedial action for the blow-out in Medicare. This so-called efficient, equitable health scheme has increased expenditure by 40 per cent over !hree years. This is a quite remarkable increase III the provision of medical services to the Australian population. Cost escalation is brought about largely by patients seeing doctors on too many occasions and, secondly, by the public perception that doctors' services are free and that the Government will pay. In any nationalised health system the delicate and responsible relationship between doctor and patient is removed. The socially responsible attitude engendered by generations of professional service by the doctors and hospitals has been demolished in two short years by Medicare. The Budget Papers indicate the magnitude of the Budget blow-out. The budget for medical services in 1984-85 was $2.5 billion compared with the $3.2 billion that was forecast in the 1986-87 Budget. This is a dramatic increase for a government and a Treasurer who claim that they have introduced a Budget of restraint and responsibility. Australian taxpayers have the Medicare levy extracted from their pay packets, along with other tax commitments. A person on average weekly earnings of $425 pays approximately $221 per annum by way of Medicare levy. If this person seeks to maintain freedom of choice and insures under private health scheme arrangements, he or she will be paying approximately $327 in insurance premiums to maintain that freedom of choice option. This makes a total of $548 to ensure the health of his or her family. Since 1971, private health insurance has dropped from 77 per cent of the population to only 50 per cent of the population being covered in 1984. The favoured socialist concept of bulk billing is pursued vigorously by the present Minister for Health. Bulk billing ensures that doctors are reduced to a common level of professional performance and that their salaries will inevitably be determined by government authorities. This contrasts with the coalition's attitude that medical practitioners are entitled to be rewarded in the free market for their skills and long years of training. The coalition will bring to an end the current Medicare arrangements and substitute an alternative health system. Incorporated in this system will be incentives for patients to seek a quality service and exercise freedom of choice for both their own doctor and hospital care. The coalition will change the emphasis to a program of preventive medicine. In undertaking this approach, the coalition will endeavour to change attitudes towards health care and promote sensible lifestyles and proper diet and exercise so that the nation's health bill can be contained. Social academic planners, far removed from the real world of Australia's health delivery services, should not be allowed to destroy a system which has been developed over the last four decades. Individual Australians wish to retain their independence in health matters. They reject the notion that health care should be nationalised, centralised and computerised.

text: Prospect) (8.00)-Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner the honourable member for Corangamite ( Mr MCArthur) in speaking on the Medicare Levy Bill made the impressive point that 28,000 people were allegedly on the waiting list for hospital beds in Victoria. Whilst I do not have the 1986 figures, it is important to remember that back in 198182 there were some 16,000 public hospital beds in Victoria and the number of occupied bed days totalled some four and a half million. The important thing to remember is that there is only a very short waiting time. These days people spend an average of only a week to 10 days in hospital. Much of the waiting time is due not to a lack of beds but to the fact that surgeons are not available or patients with particular conditions are not admitted quickly because they are not considered to be urgent cases. I do not want to go into that aspect but I do want to point out that, with nearly 80,000 public beds in Australia, waiting lists of some thousands do not matter that much. As I have said before, doctors put people on hospital waiting lists without any real intention of ever having them admitted. There are long waiting lists for operations such as tonsillectomies for children but in a high proportion of cases by the time the children come to the top of the list they no longer need the tonsillectomy. It is often in the patient's own interest to be on a waiting list. Many people here would know of my reservations about Medicare. It tends to enshrine fee for service payment for medical services. Of course it is only a compulsory health insurance scheme paid for on a progressive basis, and I support that aspect strongly because more come from those who have high incomes and those with low incomes receive complete exemption from payment. However the bad thing is, as I have said, that it does tend to enshrine fee for service payment. Because the patient does not pay, the doctor can collect much more than he could under other schemes. Therefore there is no real pressure to change the system. Medical practitioners will milk such a scheme-as would other occupational groups if they were given the same opportunity. There is therefore a tendency to provide unnecessary medical services, including consultations, pathology services, ultrasound and any other new technologies plus, most importantly from the point of view of disadvantage to the patient, unnecessary surgery including anaesthetics. Nearly every female between the age of 10 and 50 years passing through the portals of certain medical practices has a pregnancy test; everybody has a blood count; and, no matter what the symptoms, one has a good chance of having blood biochemistry performed. If one has ever coughed or wheezed, spirometer tests are taken and repeated at monthly intervals. I have no doubt that CAT scanners, magnetic resonance imaging machines and lithotripters to destroy symptomless stones in the urinary tract would probably pay for football clubs, other than those in the Victorian Football League. I personally believe, though the Department of Health does not share this view, that bulk billing is one of the features of Medicare encouraging overservicing. Some patient moietythat is, some co-payment by the patient-would act as a brake. Of course one would have to continue free medical services for those with low incomes but we have to recognise, because such a high proportion of medical services is delivered to those who are entitled to free medical services anyway-for example, pensioners, including age pensioners because as one gets older one needs more medical services-that that would probably contribute only some $30m to erasing the cost. Nonetheless, $30m is a fair bit of money. An alternative and much more preferable system is that broadly described as being based on health maintenance organisations. I congratulate the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) on his recent support of that type of service. The official definition of a health maintenance organisation is: An organisation that accepts contractual responsibility to provide a range of health care services to a voluntarily enrolled population in exchange for a predetermined, advance payment by government, individuals or by third parties. The amount of payment for each member is not affected by the frequency, extent or kind of health services they require. This system is most popular in the United States and it is interesting to note in passing that in the United States some 85 per cent of all health insurance is paid for by employers under awards. The employers have found that they are paying a very large amount in health insurance. Recently the Ford and General Motors companies found that the cost of health insurance is greater than the cost of the steel and other metals in their cars. It amounts to approximately 20 per cent of the retail price of a car, so it is a high proportion of the total costs. In practice, for those who could not follow the definition-it was probably a legalistic definition-in the health maintenance organisation system a group of medical practitioners, including most of the specialties, offers its services to individuals or lies on the basis of providing complete health cover at so much a year. It is then in the financial as well as the professional interests of those doctors to keep their patients as healthy as possible. The pooled money is divided amongst the participating doctors no matter how many services they provide. The cost of hospitalisation is carried by the pool and therefore paid for by the doctors. Total costs for HMO members are about 30 per cent less than for Blue Cross members-that is, those involved in fee for service insurance in the United States. In the United States the general hospital bed day utilisation rate is 940 bed days per 1,000 population, while for HMO members it is 424 bed days per 1,000. It is much less. In Australia, which by the way has a younger population and therefore should have less bed days per head of population, the rate is 1,484 bed days per 1,000 population. It is well over three times the rate for HMO members and about 50 per cent higher than the rate for the general population in the United States. Part of that is a result of the failure of politipractitioners' cians to make these points, and oppositions tend always-I am sure we did it-to blame governments for any hospital waiting times. Nearly every local member-I exclude myself-pushes for a hospital in his area because he feels that getting a hospital is a great achievement. All it means is that facilities are being provided for the medical profession which are probably not required. The average cost in an acute diseases hospital in Australia is in the order of $280-plus per day, so one can see the potential savings. A huge amount of money is being spent on hospitals. Of course there is a risk of underservicing associated with health maintenance organisation methods of payment vis-a-vis current overservicing. This would, of course, be prevented if people had a free choice between different systems. It is important to realise that if figures are taken from the United States America and if equal populations are compared-in other words, if people are compared on the basis of being in the same age group, of the same sex and with the same history-it will be seen that, for instance, women over 40 years of age have two and a half times greater chance of having a hysterectomy if they are privately insured with Blue Cross, which corresponds to our fee for service, compared with health maintenance organisations, and they have over three and a half times the chance of having surgery on their backs when they have a famibackache. So if a person wants to get the correct diagnosis from his doctor and is not terribly keen on surgery, it may be best to tell the doctor in the first instance that he is not privately insured. I do advocate the establishment of HMOs provided there is a safety net to catch those unable, because of financial or other reasons, to make a choice of cover. If it is possible to fund HMOs via Medicare, so much the better. I do not believe that hospital services should be separated from HMOs, otherwise there would be a strong temptation for HMO doctors to offload all medically expensive patients on to the public hospital system, which tends to happen under the United Kingdom capitation system. If a doctor gets a patient with even an infected boil or a carbuncle which involves dressing every day, he does not get paid extra for it is so he tells the patient to go to the local casualty department and get it dressed because it is much better when it is done at the hospital. We have to be careful about that. I think that the concept of HMOs is a very rational approach to try to combine medical professional incentive to provide the best care with a financial incentive. Currently the financial incentive is all the way to overservicing. The financial incentive ought to be the other way. I congratulate the Minister on pushing the HMO concept. I hope that some are established soon, that the peculiarly Australian problems can be overcome and that we can evaluate their performance and decide what system is really the best for this country.

Speaker: Mr BLANCHARD
Title: PAIRS
text: Moore) (8.25)-I rise to support the Medicare Levy Bill which is part of a package of Bills relating to the 1986-87 Budget. 1 want to use a much broader brush than did the honourable member for Gippsland ( Mr MCGauran). I think that we should briefly return to the recent history of health insurance arrangements in this country. Since the late 1960s, these arrangements have been examined and modified substantially on eight occasions. Additionally, there have been a number of lesser changes which have not substantially impacted on health insurance arrangements. Perhaps the most important, as it was the forerunner of Medicare was the introduction of Medibank on 1 July 1975. Between 1976 and 1983, the Liberal and National Party coalition reconstructed that scheme so that little of the original scheme remained. The effect of these changes was that many poor people found themselves no longer covered or inadequately covered for health care as a result of the higher costs of health insurance. The introduction of Medicare has taken health insurance arrangements back to the original Medibank principles, except that the levy has been used for funding this scheme rather than the revenue raising measures which Medibank had as a result of the obstruction by the Senate of the original scheme. Today we are discussing the Budget changes which affect Medicare, the principal one being the rise in the Medicare levy from 1 December 1986. If we examine the cost of Medicare over the past year with the projected cost for this financial year, we find that the cost of Medicare services will rise from $2,708.9m in 1985-86 to $2,999.3m in 1986-87. The cost of hospital services will rise from $2,528.6m to $2,713.2m in the next financial year. In other words, the total cost of Medicare will rise by approximately $475m. The increase in expenditure will be partially offset by increased Medicare levy collections. This Government's concern, however, for low income earners is illustrated by the cut-off points from 1 December 1986 at or below which the levy is not payable. These cut-off points mean that a single person with an income of $8,030 per annum will not be liable to pay the levy. This compares with the present cut-off point of $7,526 for single persons. The situation for married couples and sole parents is that the cut-off point will now be $13,370 per annum plus $1,660 per annum for each dependent child. This compares with the present cut-off point of $12,504 per annum plus $1,530 per annum for each dependent child. In addition, the shadingin arrangements will continue to protect people with incomes marginally above the cut-off points from the full impact of the 1.25 per cent levy. In other words, the Government has taken into consideration the financial problems of those on low incomes in meeting that levy. Let us turn to the reasons for the increase in the Medicare levy-an increase that no honourable member on this side of the HOd,lse welcomes, but we realise that a difficult choice had to be made. The Budget was presented at a time when, because of difficult economic circumstances, the belt had to be tightened. All government expenditure and revenue had to be closely scrutinised, and Medicare was no exception to that rule. Benefits and payments by the State under Medicare cost $3,625m in 1985-86, which was nearly 5 per cent of government expenditure. Given the choice of reducing the deficit by either increasing revenue or reducing expenditure, the Government opted in this case to increase revenue. It preferred this to destroying the essential features of Medicare. The main advantage of this approach is that it preserves the Government's commitment to provide a health insurance scheme based on the principles of fairness, simplicity, universality and cost efficiency. It preserves the 85 per cent rebate and thus, by protecting bulk billing, continues to ensure universal access to necessary medical services. It maintains fairness by ensuring that the burden of paying for health care is spread across the whole community on the basisÂ· of ability to pay and does not fall mainly on sick people, many of whom are the most vulnerable in the community. It is also consistent with the Government's call for restraint with equity as the levy arrangements exempt the financially disadvantaged, as I showed earlier, and ensure that the cost of health care is spread throughout the rest of the community. This means that there are no consumer price index effects, with all the consequent fiowons, as there would have been if other options such as reducing the rebate had been adopted. At a time of falling revenues, it ensures that the inevitable increases in the cost of medical services, which largely follow historical trends, are not paid at the expense of cutbacks in other government programs financed out of general revenue. A number of factors have contributed to cost increases. These factors are worth mentioning in view of some of the alarmist statements made by members of the Opposition. Firstly, under Medicare there has been better access to necessary care. This does not mean that the Government can be complacent. There is still need for further improvements. But a large number of people who previously were uninsured under the disastrous health schemes of the Opposition when it was in government are now covered under Medicare. Secondly, population growth through both natural increase and immigration has caused additional strains on Medicare, as indeed has the aging of our population, which is the third factor and one which, I remind the House, correlates with an efficient health service. The fourth factor is the rapidly increasing number of doctors seeking incomes commensurate with their training and perceived status. Finally, there has been increased average benefit levels for service from greater use of medical technology and specialist services. However, the comments of the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) in respect of fee for service are worthy of note in this regard. The call that we he.ar from the Opposition benches for the abolition of a health scheme which is based on the principles of fairness, simplicity, universality and cost efficiency unforcent, tunately illustrates the poverty of health policies within the Liberal and National parties. Medicare provides the equitable way of providing Australians with health cover. I therefore support the Bill.
