Title: PAIRS
text: I thank the Minister for Trade for his comments, but I suggest to him that an important piece of legislation such as this demands the attention in the chamber of the responsible Minister. The Medicare Levy Bill would be more appropriately termed the Medicare Tax Bill 1986, because it represents an additional tax of 1.25 per cent on taxable income, which is a rise of 25 per cent over and above the one per cent levy which has been in place for two years. The Hawke socialist Government is a big taxing and very big spending government. I point out that the levy has risen by 25 per cent and the services have gone down. Mr O'Keefe-Rubbish!

Speaker: Mr HODGES
Title: PAIRS
text: It is true. The tax has risen and the services have diminished. Let me point out to the House how this has happened. Two weeks ago in this chamber we debated the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No.2) 1986, which provided for the abolition of the private hospital bed subsidy. That will save this Government something to the tune of $143m in a full year. We find that patients now have to pay a maximum of $20 per service, which is up from $10 per service previously. They are just two examples of how services have diminished while the levy has risen from one per cent to 1.25 per an increase of 25 per cent. This big taxing Government has introduced a capital gains tax. It has introduced a fringe benefits tax and does not know where it is going with that tax. It is saving revenue through an assets test on pensioners. I point out to the chamber and to the nation that the Opposition Liberal and National parties, when in government, will repeal the assets test and the fringe benefits tax, or throw it out lock, stock and barrel, as the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Howard) has claimed, and will abolish the capital gains tax. Medicare is costing this nation about $4.7 billion. That is an approximate cost because it is very difficult to pinpoint the exact cost. This levy of 1.25 per cent on taxable income will raise $1.645 billion. The expenditure of $3 billion over and above that will come out of Consolidated Revenue. Therefore, the shortfall-the difference between the $4.7 billion cost of Medicare and the $I,645m raised by the levy-will come out of Consolidated Revenue. In one second reading speech from the Minister he stated that 52 per cent of all medical services under Medicare are bulk billed. I suggest to him that the 52 per cent figure that he cites, and indeed boasts about, is one of which he ought to be ashamed. The Opposition's policy clearly states that pensioners and disadvantaged people will be bulk billed. But people will have the right either to stay in Medicare and pay the Medicare levy or to opt out of Medicare provided that they take out health insurance with a private health insurance fund. At present, because of the desire of thousands of Australians to have private hospital insurance in order to be treated by the doctor of their choice in a hospital of their choice, many people pay much higher health contributions than should be the case. The present Medicare system has only one advantage over the Opposition's policy-only a very slight advantage-and that is that it is simple to operate. It is simple and it is very, very expensive. Any advantage one might obtain from the simplicity of the system is utterly negated by its expense. Let us look at bulk billing, which I believe should be abolished, except for pensioners and the disadvantaged. The present system of bulk billing encourages both patients and doctors to abuse and overuse the system. People should be made more responsible for their own affairs and actions. The Government should get out of their lives as far as possible. There should always be an identifiable cost to the patient for any service and that is, as I have said, with the exception of pensioners and the disadvantaged. Patients and doctors will be careful if there is an identifiable cost. The Opposition's policy is promotion of independence. We will have a nation of people fending for themselves, making their own decisions. But the Hawke socialist Government is about dependence-having a maximum number of people reliant on government and government services. It wants a nation of jellyfish, with no backbone, drifting around aimlessly, being controlled by the Government and the bureaucracy. Medicare is a disaster on two fronts. First, it is a financial disaster. In introducing the Medicare legislation the Minister quite clearly stated that the one per cent levy would substantially fund Medicare. I quote from the Minister's speech in this chamber on 6 September 1983 in which he said: But I do not resile from openly stating that the principles of the Medicare plan are similar to those of Medibank as it was originally introduced in 1975. There are two important differences. Medicare will be tially self-funding through the one per cent levy and a rearrangement of existing health insurance subsidies, whereas Medibank placed a considerable strain on Consolidated Revenue. I liked his comparison between Medibank, which placed a considerable strain on Consolidated Revenue, and Medicare, which would not do so. I suggest that the Minister should take another look at the figures and see what Medicare is costing the nation in its drain on Consolidated Revenue. Again, in this chamber on 15 May 1985 in the debate on the Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1985, the Minister stated: The additional cost of the Medicare program remains substantially funded through the fair, income-related levy. The words 'additional cost' obviously were related to changes to health legislation made in that Bill. But the Minister repeated himself and said that the Medicare program remained substantially funded through the fair, income-related levy. As I pointed out, $4.7 billion is as close as I can get the estimate of Medicare in this financial year. The tax would need to be some 3 per cent if it were to cover, as the Minister has stated, substantially the outgoings of Medicare in the 1986-87 financial year. In addition to the disaster that Medicare is financially, it is also a disaster when it comes to the provision of hospital services. Noone has put the case more convincingly and with a greater number of examples than has the shadow Minister for Health, the honourable member for Barker EmptyHere almost unknown. I have seen figures that vary up to 60,000 and more as to the number of people on waiting lists for operations. Only acute cases are handled in the majority of public hospitals throughout this nation. Yet the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) told us in unequivocal terms that all Australians will have a bed made available to them in a public hospital. Some 60 per cent of Australians had private health insurance to cover them for hospitalisation. With Medicare this dropped to about 47 per cent, and I understand that the figure has now improved to a little over 50 per cent. I want to make a few comments relative to the operations of Medibank Private and its association with Medicare. There is an unfair advantage that Medibank Private has over the other private health insurance funds due to the joint arrangement of Medibank Private and Medicare. In most instances they have common offices; they have a common staff; there are cash payment facilities for Medicare in Medibank Prisubstan- vate offices. Why does not the Minister for Health make more private health insurance funds agents for Medicare? At present they have a one-stop shopping arrangement. This is of great advantage to Medibank Private. If they had more private health insurance funds as agents for Medicare, it would improve the service to the public. Surely that is important to us all. It would break the monopoly of Medibank Private, which, by all standards and evaluations, is unfair. The Voluntary Health Insurance Association of Australia has made numerous approaches to the Minister for Health to have Medicare operate through its agency outlets, but the firm response from the Minister has been no. Management expenses of Medicare and Medibank are low because the Australian Taxation Office acts as collector for Medicare. Would the Minister say what charge the Taxation Office makes on the Health Insurance Commission for collecting the $1.645 billion raised through Medicare? If one examines the 1984-85 report of the Health Insurance Commission one notes an apportionment of expenditure between Medicare and Medibank Private. The Auditor-General was very critical of the Health Insurance Commission in the 1984-85 report in the following terms: The Commission has not, however, provided sufficient evidence to enable me to assess the reasonableness of the actual apportionment it has made. Consequently, I am unable to assess the fairness of the apportionment of these costs presented in the financial statements. The total of management expenses for Medicare and Medibank Private is not in question. That is proof that there is an advantage to Medibank Private as a private health fund. I wonder whether the Minister has provided evidence to the Auditor-General since that Auditor-General's report was made. I very much doubt whether he has. I turn to another disturbing aspect of this apportionment of expenditure between Medicare and Medibank Private. I quote again from the Health Insurance Commission's report: This amendment, which has the effect of increasing by $7.588m the costs borne by Medibank Private, is necessary to ensure an equitable distribution. ciples applied in 1984/85 were not determined by the Minister until 21 November 1985. As the Health Insurance Commission Act does not permit retrospective application by the Commission a breach of section 34C(2) has occurred. This clearly indicates that the Minister and the Health Insurance Commission are derelict in their duties. Almost five months of the 1984-85 financial year passed before the Minister determined new principles for apportionment of costs between Medibank Private and Medicare. This is a disgrace involving a Commission that would allow five months of the year to pass and not get directions from the Minister, and a Minister who was not advised adequately to ensure that that aspect of the operations of the Health Insurance Commission was tidied up. The operations of Medibank Private offices in conjunction with Medicare will receive a great boost from the revocation by the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) as notified in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette of Monday, 18 August 1986. Appendix H of the 1984-85 Health Insurance Commission report gives ministerial directions relating to Medibank Private under sub-section 8F (I) of the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973. That ministerial direction restricts the number of Medibank Private offices and Medicare offices that can operate in conjunction. This revocation in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette to which I referred opens the door for Medibank Private, through its association with Medicare, to compete with a substantial unfair advantage over the other private health insurance funds. In effect, Medibank Private is not really a private health fund. It likes to claim that it is, but in effect it is not. So we will see an even greater number of combined Medibank Private-Medicare offices. Obviously, because of financial considerations, they will be able to close offices in positions that are not as accessible as they would like and they will be able to open new offices in highly trafficked areas in our cities and provincial towns. No doubt that unfair advantage will mean they will take a considerable amount of business from the other private health care funds. The 1984-85 Health Insurance Commission report shows that there were 195 joint Medibank Private-Medicare offices and 69 Medicare-only offices, making a total of 264 in Australia. Indeed, there are 12 regionally based private health funds that provide a cash payment facility for a specified range of Medicare services. That is an indication that Medicare has been and should be prepared to extend those payout facilities through private The prin- health insurance funds other than Medibank Private. I conclude by drawing the attention of the House to the speech made by the Minister for Health in this chamber two weeks ago on the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No.2) 1986 when he stated that, because of accumulated levels of funds in a number of the private health funds, increases as a result of the abolition of the private hospital bed day subsidy should be 'moderate'. Title: PAIRS
text: Burke) (8.56)-The honourable member for Petrie ( Mr Hodges) made one comment during his discourse that gave some credit to the current Medicare scheme. He said that if it was nothing else at least it was simple. I shall add just three other features which I think tell the whole story in a few words. Not only is the Medicare system simple, but it is also cheap, fair and, most important, it works. I shall come back to the point about its working and talk about the pathetic attempts of the previous Government to introduce a health system to Australia that worked and was cheap and simple. Those are the criteria that the Opposition has established. The Medicare Levy Bill brings about the Budget measure increasing the Medicare levy. I believe that it should be supported and I have no problems in supporting it in the House. I take up the first comment made by the honourEmptyHere this debate this afternoon. He referred to the 'broken promises of the Hawke Government' on the Medicare levy. He is just the person to stand here and talk about broken promises. If we look at the performance of his Government in the area of health care, the most significant broken promise of the Fraser-Howard years that comes to mind-and I will put aside the great tax grabback which I thought was the most memorable broken promise-was: 'We will not dismantle Medibank'. That was the promise that Opposition members made to the people in 1975. What did we see? We not only saw them dismantle Medibank, but they tried, one after the other, four hotchpotches of medical insurance schemes in an effort to cobble together a scheme that would hold and keep the health care system in Australia in some semblance of order. Of course, they failed. One of the very big planks of this Government, upon which it was elected in March 1983, was the restoration of a universal health scheme and the implementation of Medicare. Medicare is not only one of the promises that have been successfully implemented by this Government, but also one of the features of this Government's successes within the economy. I wish to mention a number of the issues that were raised by both the honourable member for Barker and the honourable member for Petrie. I suppose I should start by focusing on the interests that those members represent. I think it is well known to everyone in this House that the Liberal Party of Australia has always aligned its health policies primarily to appeal to the largest private interests in the health sector-not the ordinary person, not the pensioners, not the sick, not the disabled, but the largest private interests in the health sector. These include private doctors, private hospitals and private health insurance companies. Those are the interests who dictate Liberal health policies and that is why the Opposition will continue to be rejected by the people of Australia. Opposition members are now renewing their noises about destroying Medicare and returning to some mishmash of failed health schemes which existed in the past. What would that mean? It would mean the same as it meant in the past-that the wealthier in our society would pay less for health care and lower income earners would pay more. That is what we can thank Fraser for and that is what we would have to thank Howard for if we were to consider seriously any of his propositions in the health sector. Let us look at some of the features that the Opposition has chosen to highlight in this debate. Once again Opposition members have chosen to focus on the question of health insurance rather than the issue of better health care. That has always been the position in the political debate in Australia. For years the political arguments about health in this country have been about the provision of health insurance rather than the provision of better health care. In other words, they continually focus upon the interests of those who make the dough out of health. Not surprisingly, Medicare has retained its public rating as the popular health system. The fact that it has undergone very few changes in its three-year history makes it the most stable health system in this country in the last decade. That is a point that is worth repeating: It is the most stable health system in this country in the last decade. Not only has it been that but I can tell honourable members opposite that it is here to stay. Let us talk about fraud and overservicing. When one listens to honourable members opposite one may think that fraud and overservicing by doctors and all the others who have been exposed in the last two years by this Government started only in February 1984 when Medicare was introduced. We know that that is nonsense. We know that fraud and overservicing and the problems of the health industry in this area have existed for the last 20 years. Not only have they existed for the last 20 years but also during the Opposition's period in office the problems in our community were exacerbated by the then Government's appalling performance in relation to tax avoidance and its allowing of these people not only to get into this area of fraud and overservicing but also to hide extraordinarily high incomes that were extracted in these ways within the tax system without any semblance of social responsibility or direction by that Governcommend ment. The Opposition has much to answer for, and I have no doubt that people in Australia will not forget that. Honourable members opposite talk about the cost of health insurance. Not long ago the shadow Minister for Health, the honourable member for Barker, claimed that under the Opposition's health policy it would cost the ordinary family only $400 a year for basic hospital insurance. We know that it already costs $7 a week, or $350 a year, for ordinary family hospital insurance, and that is with a $1 billion Medicare subsidy built into the hospital system. Honourable members opposite are talking about removing that hospital cover. If it alone were removed we would be talking about it costing $700 per year per family. That is double what people are paying now. Let us not sit in here and listen to this nonsense that the honourable member for Barker goes on with. He cannot have it both ways. He cannot talk about saving the $2,500m that he claims the Opposition's policy could save and then talk about funding it in some other way that would not cost people in premiums. It is nonsense, and people know that it is nonsense. We have heard honourable members opposite talk tonight about how they would abolish direct billing. Let us look at that issue. The Liberal Party is the first political party in my memory to come into this House and advocate that it would abolish direct billing. No one has talked about abolishing direct billing for pensioners and other welfare beneficiaries. We all know that about 70 per cent of direct billing in Australia comes from that sector. If one were to abolish direct billing in the other areas one would be talking about very marginal savings. Not even the Opposition is saying that it would abolish direct billing for pensioners and other welfare recipients. It is nonsense to stand up in this place, as did the honourable member for Petrie, and claim that the Opposition would achieve all these savings in this way. Honourable members opposite talk about waiting lists. I think this is one of the more despicable claims that they make because, by inference, they are intending to put to this House that in some way Medicare is responsible for public hospital waiting lists. We really have to return to the fact that Medicare is a health insurance system, not a health service delivery system. Let us look at some of the reasons for the delays in public hospitals in Australia. There is a shortage of nurses which some of the State governments are addressing very aggressively. I the Victorian Government for its attempts to build up very quickly the number of nurses and their career structure in that State. We are looking also at the issue within our community of new technology, new equipment and new methods of delivering health services. When people are ill or when they are facing major operations they want the best that the health world can provide. It is extremely costly. The technology, the provision of the services and the training of the people are costly. No one resiles from that fact. The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) is anxious to see the most efficient and the highest standard of health care service that the nation can deliver. No one on this side of the House pretends to purport that that has anything at all to do with the health insurance system which involves the Medicare levy which we are debating. text: Yes, what a joke. It is a key element in this Labor Government's compulsory national health insurance scheme that the Medicare levy is designed to fund the provision of medical care only partially. It will be recalled by all honourable members that the Medicare levy was introduced on 1 February 1984 at an annual rate of one per cent of taxable income. In addition, we were told that it would pay for the additional cost of this abortion of a scheme. The one per cent levy applies for the time being to all residents and it is subject to certain exemptions for incomes above specifically defined thresholds. The Treasurer ( Mr Keating) in his Budget statement announced that the Medicare levy would be increased by 0.25 of one per cent to 1.25 per cent in total of relevant taxable income as from 1 December 1986. It was the final blow to follow all the insincerities that we heard from the Prime Minister and the Minister for Health at the outset and since the introduction of Medicare. As the Budget Papers made clear, on page 285, for the purpose of the assessment of provisional taxation: The Medicare levy will be a weighted average of the present rate of 1% (5/12 weight) and the rate to apply from I December 1986 (7/12 weight). The Bill establishes the levy for this year, 198687, as 1.145 per cent, and until Parliament otherwise provides, the levy will be 1.25 per cent in 1987-88. Given the treachery of this measure, no one can have any faith in relation to retaining the 1.25 per cent figure in 1987-88. Before an election-although it is unlikely that we would have to suffer another period under this Government-no one could be reassured by any suggestion that the levy will be limited to 1.25 per cent under this Government. The estimated increase in revenue as a result of this measure is $175m for 1986-87 and $325m in a full year. On page 295 of the Budget Statements we find that the Medicare revenue estimate for 1986-87 is $1,645m. That figure comprise!! $1.375 billion from pay as you earn taxpayers and $270m from other individuals. This represents 2.3 per cent of total receipts and is a massive 23.2 per cent increase on 1985-86. It must be recalled, and it should be emphasised time and again, as it has been already by my colleagues on this side including the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Barker, EmptyHere 1984 election policy speech: And now I give this undertaking-that for the term of our next government the Medicare levy will not be increased. In light of that deception and on top of a myriad of other prime ministerial deceptions, one would think that not much else needed to be said. However, the Prime Minister compounded that episode in February of 1986, when he said: I affirm that the Government has no plans to change the Medicare arrangement. He has started to play with words. The following month the Minister for Health became involved in the subterfuge when he said on an Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio program: Well the Prime Minister has made it quite clear at the election and in a recent statement that there is no consideration of changing the Medicare levy. The Minister for Health chose his words less carefully than did the Prime Minister. I do not believe there is a soul in this country who would say that the Minister was serious when he said that no consideration had been given to changing the levy. That is simply not believable. There is no doubt in anyone's mind that this Government has considered changing the levy since it first introduced this scheme, and the Minister, by using those words, showed himself to be less than careful and certainly not in the same league as the Prime Minister when it comes to practising deception. This Bill increases the rate of the Medicare levy from one per cent to 1.25 per cent and adjusts the threshold limit below which the levy is not payable. It is a Budget measure and as such will not be opposed by the Opposition parties. Nonetheless, some further comments do need to be made about the Government's compulsory health insurance scheme. Medicare, introduced in 1984, provided 85 per cent coverage of the scheduled fee for medical services and 'free'-that is to say, taxpayer funded-public hospital accommodation. In 1984-85 the cost to the public purse of medical benefits totalled $2,240m while expenditure on public hospitals totalled something like $924.5m-a total of $3,164m. In that year the Medicare levy raised $1,150m. In 1985-86 expenditure totalled $3,634.6m. Of that, $2,589.3m was expended on medical benefits and $1,063.3m was spent on public hospital charges. That is the measure of the increase in these two or three short years. Revenue from the levy was estimated in 198586 at around $1,335m. In 1986-87 public hospitals are to receive $1,075.4m and it is estimated that $2,866.2m will be spent on medical benefits-a total figure of around $3,939.6m. Should this Bill receive the approval of the Parliament, the levy will increase to 1.25 per cent, and that is the reason we are debating this measure tonight. As I have already explained, this will mean an effective levy rate of 1.45 per cent for this financial year. We are told that this would result in revenue rising to an estimated $1,645m-23.2 per cent higher than in 1985-86. So there we have it. That is the measure of the increase we are talking about. Federal Government spending on medical care has increased by 27 per cent over the last two years and the 1986-87 Budget Papers predict that it will have risen by 40 per cent by the end of this year. As my colleague the shadow Minister for Health noted recently, a major contributing factor to this rise is increased utilisation fostered by bulk billing. Labor has established an almost openended system of unlimited access to free-perhaps that should be in inverted commas-medical care; that is to say, taxpayer funded medical care. Let me dwell for a moment on one of the idiosyncrasies that arise out of these Budget measures. I have been advised that, under present tax regulations relating to Medicare, single members of the Defence Force are exempt from the levy. Married members are required to pay half the levy whether or not their spouse is working and regardless of whether there are children. For the purpose of Medicare, a spouse is considered to be a dependant of the member regardless of that spouse's income. This means that, if a member of the Force marries and the spouse continues working, the member is liable to pay half the levy and the spouse pays full levy in his or her own right if above the tax-free threshold. There is no justice in this arrangement-not that we think the present Government is concerned with justice-as the member of the Force can gain no extra benefit until there are children or until the spouse ceases work. However, the member immediately loses half the benefit provided by his or her conditions of employment. I can imagine what the unions would do in similar circumstances. The coalition parties are justified, if only by this one example, in heaping criticism on these measures. Mr John Logan, a specialist in the area of health economics, contributed a chapter to a recent book entitled Policies and Prescriptions: Current Directions in Health Policy, published in May this year by the Centre for Independent Studies. The Centre is a fine organisation. Its publications have a well deserved international reputation and its research into economic and social issues compares favourably with that carried out by the many publicly funded tertiary institutions in this country. Logan's chapter deals with the crucial issue of government intervention in health care. While not necessarily agreeing with all his remarks, I commend the chapter, and indeed the whole book, to the attention of honourable members. Logan traces the history of government involvement in the provision of health care and makes a number of valuable comments, two of which I want to emphasise. The first is that the size of the Government's monetary stake in health care, to which I referred earlier, understates the true extent of its influence. The author notes on page 55: The controls and regulations that abound as a result of government involvement alter people's incentives in certain ways and thus cause them to behave differently. Resource misallocation, inefficiency, cost increases irrecoverable waste are generally the results. That is it in a nutshell. Medicare has proven hopelessly inefficient. The 100,000 Australians who are currently awaiting essential surgery in our massively overcrowded public hospitals bear testimony to that. What is worse, as Logan points out, controls over the behaviour of health care providers have: helped to steer us in the direction of a full blown national health system complete with doctors as Government employees; poorly used hospital resources and rationing by waiting in line . . . What is necessary is a refocusing of attention onto the needs of patients and their families and incentives to cost containment that recognise simple economic and social realities. As a first step to reforming the Australian health care system the next coalition government will take three key steps: First, Australians will be free to opt out of Medicare and to avoid the levy provided they take out private insurance; second, except for those who really need it, bulk billing will be abolished; third, we will free up the health insurance market by allowing it to operate in innovative ways and offer health care consumers a variety of packages that recognise legitimate choices by individuals. Individualising the insurance program for health care brings the cost factor directly back into the market-place between the citizen and the health care provider. It increases the individual's self-interest in good health and breaks away from our current system which encourages both patient and provider to be less responsible, because neither has any direct individual concern about the cost. It encourages our plan; that is, it encourages people to believe that health care is merely a benefit without also involving complementary cost. This is so with the present system. It is particularly so at the margins where access to health services is utilised even when care is not necessary or on occasion is not required by all. It is a nonsense for the Government and its supporters to claim that the Medicare system as it now stands or as it will be after these amendments should be fairer, simpler or cheaper. It is just not the case and it will not be the case until the policies I have mentioned of the coalition parties are put into effect, and that will be almost certainly after the next election.

Title: BANK ACCOUNT DEBITS TAX
text: Order! I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.3) 1986 with the Bank Account Debits Tax Amendment Bill 1986. As there is no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

Speaker: Mr CARLTON
Title: BANK ACCOUNT DEBITS TAX
text: Mackellar) (9.56)-Once again we are debating taxation laws. It seem that we debate little else these days. That, of course, derives from the Government's demand for more and more money from taxpayers to pay for its excessive spending. The Opposition will not oppose the revenue measures in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.3) 1986 and the Bank Account Debits Tax Amendment Bill 1986. However, as an amendment to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No.3) 1986, I move: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: 'whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for(I) its failure to control Government spending to the point where it has broken its 'Trilogy' commitment to hold taxation to no more than 25 per cent of gross domestic product and proceeded to tax Australians to the highest point in our history; (2) its contempt for ordinary taxpayers, illustrated by its decision to charge a $200 fee for appeals against rulings by the Commissioner of Taxation regardless of the size or complexity of the claim; (3) its incompetent handling of the withholding tax issue, where the Government changed the tax rules, caused a run on the dollar, and retreated 27 days later, and ( 4) its disgraceful treatment of the Defence Forces Reserves, by withdrawing the tax free status of reservists' pay thereby causing a grave rundown of reserve forces and damage to their morale and effectiveness, and now having belatedly to restore the concession'. The first item I shall deal with, which is in the second Bill, is a straight tax increase. Bank account debits tax is up from I December to bring in an extra $90m of revenue in a full year. This extra $90m is part of the $1,500m extra tax levied in this 1986 Budget. It is a further burden on taxpayers either directly through their bank accounts or by additional costs, charges and prices that go through the community as a result of the additional burden on business. The reason (No.3) 1986 we must have, under this Government, an extra $90m drawn out of our bank accounts is that the Government is spending too much. The degree to which it is spending too much is shown up in the degree to which it has been forced to Second Reading increase overall levels of taxation. In the last election campaign, the Prime Minister ( Mr Hawke) promised that government spending would be held in check and that, as a result, taxation on the Australian people would be kept within a limit of 25 per cent of the gross domestic product. In this Budget, for the second year running, that trilogy commitment has been broken. It has already been exceeded by $1,40Om in extra tax. Part of that has come from a threemonth delay in the cuts in personal iIicome tax, costing taxpayers on average $110 each. In other words, because of the delay in the tax cuts for three months, the average taxpayer will pay to the Government an extra $110 over the next three months. In addition to that, there have been increases in sales tax, which we debated in the last sitting week, and increases in the petrol excise which are a very severe burden particularly on lower income families. The House may wish to be reminded that, since the Hawke Government came to office, the petrol excise has risen from 6.2c a litre to 20.2 cents a litre. It has risen by a total of 14c a litre. That represents $6.30 a week for the average motorist. For a low income family with a car and living in the outer suburbs, that represents an extra $6.30 a week in petrol tax since the Hawke Government came to office. Of course, the Government says that individual taxpayers will be assisted by the tax cuts that they will get, though belatedly, on I December. But one has to be pretty sceptical about this because, if one looks at the overall amount of income tax collected by the Hawke Government, it has risen from a 1982-83 figure under the Fraser Government of $23 billion to $38 billion in the 1986-87 Budget. In other words, total taxation revenue has risen from $23 billion in the last year of the Fraser Government to $38 billion under the Hawke Government. The Hawke Government is the highest taxing government in Australia's history. It has almost doubled the total taxation take from the Australian people in its four years in office-from $23 billion in the last Fraser Budget year of 1982-83 to $38 billion in the 1986 Hawke-Keating Budget. During the period of the Hawke Government there has been an overall increase in infiatioIl' of 30.5 per cent but the increase in taxation on individuals has risen by 60 per cent, by twice the level of inflation. So inflation has risen by 30 per cent and taxation by 60 per cent. That is what is happening under this Government which has promised taxation cuts to people. In fact, the taxation cuts that people are to get will not reduce the amount of tax paid by average taxpayers, but will increase it. At the time that the Hawke Government was elected in 1983, the average rate of tax paid by a single person was 22.9c in the dollar. After all of these so-called cuts have been given, that average rate will have risen from 22.9c to 24.5c in the dollar. Even after all of these changes and after the cuts promised for next year-which we probably will not get because we are threatened with a miniBudget to take them away-a single taxpayer will still pay a higher average rate of tax. A family will be even worse off. In March 1983 when the Hawke Government came to office a family taxpayer on average weekly earnings would have paid 17.5 per cent of income tax. That figure will rise to 20.5 per cent after the so-called Keating tax reforms. What we are seeing is a desperation for taxpayers' money. That is why the Government desperately hangs on to its absurd, lousy fringe benefits tax. The Government is desperate for revenue to cover its excessive spending. Under the Government's changes, two million taxpayers will move from a 29 per cent top tax rate to a 40 per cent top tax rate. It sounds good when one says that the top marginal rate under the so-called tax reform will be reduced from 46c in the dollar to 40c in the dollar and that the 30c rate will be reduced to 29c; but, when one realises that over the course of the two years because of inflation two million taxpayers will move from a 29 per cent top tax rate to a 40 per cent tax rate, one realises that the whole thing is a massive swindle. Over the next few months we will see an attempt by this Government to tell people that they will have reductions in tax but, because of the effects of inflation and of the excessive spending of this Government, people will be much worse off after these so-called reforms are implemented. An average Australian family will still be $23.50 a week worse off after the lousy tax cuts from 1 December this year. Since the last election a one-income family on average weekly earnings of $466 and with two dependent children has suffered a real loss in disposable income of $27 a week. The weekly tax saving for the 1986-87 year for someone on average weekly earnings of $466 will be only $3.50. This means that the average family is still $23.50 worse off since the last election. So much for the great tax reforms of the present Treasurer ( Mr Keating). The Prime Minister and the Treasurer have again demonstrated their total lack of concern for Australian families by failing to give them any meaningful tax relief. The reason is that they have spent too much over four years and have almost doubled the amount of tax taken from the Australian public. I wish to draw attention to another miserable little measure in these Bills. I refer to the introduction of a $200 lodgement fee if one wishes to appeal against a decision of the Commissioner of Taxation. Previously, if one wanted to appeal one paid $2. But, under these new proposals, the charge of $2 will suddenly become $200. I have received two letters from chartered accountants who handle the tax matters of small business clients. I will quote from them as a direct indication of the effect of this increase on small taxpayers. A chartered accountant from Canberra writes as follows: It appears to me that the referral fee is particularly going to disadvantage those persons in the lower income group. By this I mean that it will not be worthwhile referring the matter to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal if the value of the tax involved is less than $200. A person who is in the lower income group and paying tax at the rate of 24.42c in the dollar will be most severely disadvantaged. The disallowance which represents an amount of $200 in tax in this particular case is $819. In other words, if somebody has $819 disallowed it will not be worth their paying the fee to have it looked at again. On the other hand, a person paying tax at the highest rate, namely 57.08c in the dollar need only have a disallowance of $350 in claims to equal the $200 in tax. In other words, the higher one's income, the better off one is with his $200 fee. The people on the lowest incomes and the lowest tax rates will be the ones most disadvantaged. That is normally the case with anything done by a socialist government. It is always the people who are worse off who finish up at the end of the queue. The letter continues: The idea of referring a taxation objection or disallowance to the Board of Review, now the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, was to provide a cheap and inexpensive way for a taxpayer to have a person or persons outside the Taxation Office review their objection. Un-Â· der the new arrangement involving a referral fee, it would appear that this cheap and inexpensive method has now gone and only those with substantial claims will proceed. My additional concern is that the Taxation Office may take the attitude of disallowing the smaller claim en masse with the object of having raised further revenue unjustly. This is something that cannot be checked by parliamentarians but the system now is certainly open to abuse by the Taxation Office. In other words, the tax office might take advantage of this by knocking out willy-nilly a whole lot of small claims-this is what the accountant is saying-because it will not be worth the while of those small taxpayers to pay the $200 fee to have the matter challenged. I have with me another letter from a chartered accountant in Melbourne, who goes into the matter in a different way. He says: The imposition of a fee at a level of $200 would make referral of some matters beyond the reach of a large number of taxpayers. This fee appears to be aimed at the removal of the legal rights for a large group of the community who are 'small taxpayers'. In the case of a dispute over the disallowance of a small expense item in a husband and wife partnershiphere one is talking, I suppose, about small businessto pursue the matter beyond the objection level will cost each partner $200-that is, $400 in respect of one item in dispute. So if in a small business partnership of man and wife there is an objection, each partner will have to pay $200. It simply will not be worth the candle, if they have to pay $400 to have a matter looked at. What sort of a government is it that brings in things of this kind? Mr Barry Cohen-A terrific government.

Speaker: Mr CARLTON
Title: BANK ACCOUNT DEBITS TAX
text: The Minister says that this is a terrific government. He says that it is a terrific government which brings in a $200 objection fee which has its greatest effect on the smallest taxpayers, those who have the least money to cope with it. That is the sort of government this Minister is proud of. The next matter I shall deal with tonightand I shall continue my remarks tomorrow because we are running out of time-relates to the interest withholding tax fiasco. This is an extraordinary story. On I July the Treasurer made the statement that to protect Commonwealth revenues the Government had decided to remove a number of exemptions from interest withholding tax. I shall not go into the complications, but it meant that a number of people who had widely held securities overseas, or if there were borrowings by Commonwealth and State authorities, rollovers and extensions of loans which were exempt from interest withholding tax-the tax paid before the interest is sent back overseas to the person who has made the loanhad those exemptions removed. That was to raise net revenue of $60m in 1986-87, rising to $175m in later years. This was a stupid, ill-timed decision. Following the decision, the Australian dollar dropped to a new record low. It went down to 55.2 on the trade weighted index, 66.5c against the United States dollar and 108.6 against the yen. It hit new record lows on 2 and 3 July following the I July announcement. Over the rest of July things went from bad to worse. Despite large and costly Reserve Bank intervention, on 28 July the Australian dollar continued to drop and it plummeted to 50.c on the trade weighted index and only 60.3 against the United States dollar, a drop of 6.2c over the also course of less than a month. The Treasurer panicked and, in an attempt to stem the slide of the dollar on that fateful day, he announced the reversal of the I July decision to close off the interest withholding tax exemptions. It was a black day on I July 1986 for Australia because the overseas financial markets could not understand what the Australian Government had done. It suddenly changed a whole lot of arrangements upon which people had relied for years, the dollar plummeted and over the course of a month went down 6c against the United States dollar. The Treasurer was shamefacedly forced to reverse this decision only 28 days later. It was one of the most shameful examples of mismanagement by this Treasurer during a period of office which has been marked increasingly by mismanagement in a whole range of areas. Speaker: Mr LANGMORE
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Fraser) (1O.l9)-In preparation for the Pope's visit to Australia, the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace and Australian Catholic Relief have published a selection of John Paul II's statements about issues relating to justice and peace. I found great value in reading these excerpts in the pamphlet 'Founded on Justice and Peace' and so would like to bring them to the attention of honourable members. While the aim of the pamphlet is to promote study and reflection among members of the Catholic Church, those of us who are not Catholics will also find a great deal of relevance in its pages and I wholeheartedly commend it to members of Parliament. 'Founded on Justice and Peace' brings together statements of Pope John Paul II on some of the major issues of our time. Its publication follows in the tradition of the CCJP's earlier statements 'Work for a Just Peace' in 1985, 'It's a Rocky Road'-on youth-in 1984, 'Changing Australia' in 1983, 'House and Home'-on housing-in 1982, 'Partners: Australia, Asia and the Pacific' in 1981, 'Poverty, Power and the Church' in 1980, 'Beyond Unemployment' in 1979 and 'Aborigines' in 1978. The 1986 statement shows that the somewhat controversial issues which the CCJP has written about in earlier years have a firm basis in the social teaching of Pope John Paul II. For example, on the economy he has said: In various parts of the world, in various socio-economic systems, there exists entire areas of poverty, shortage and underdevelopment. This fact is universally known. The state of inequality between individuals and between nations not only still exists; it is increasing. It still happens that side by side with those who are wealthy and living in plenty there exist those who are living in want, suffering misery and often actually dying of hunger; and their number reaches tens, even hundreds of millions. This is why moral uneasiness is destined to become even more acute. It is obvious that a fundamental defect, or rather a series of defects, indeed a defective machinery is at the root of contemporary economics and materialistic civilisation, which does not allow the human family to break free from such radically unjust situations. On the arms race and the search for peace, Pope John Paul has said: Instead of bread and cultural aid, the new States and nations awakening to independent life are being offered, sometimes in abundance, modern weapons and means of destruction placed at the service of armed conflicts and wars that are not so much a requirement for defending their sovereignty, but rather a form of chauvinism, imperialism and neocolonialism of one kind or another. We all know very well that the areas of misery and hunger on our globe could have been made fertile in a short time, if the gigantic investments for armaments at the service of war and destruction had been changed into investments for food The Pope's well-known respect for indigenous cultures is also highlighted in a passage from a speech to the Indians of Guatemala, when he said: Your native cultures are the wealth of peoples, tive ways for transmitting the faith, representations of your relation with God, with all men, and with the world. They therefore deserve the greatest respect, esteem, sympathy and support on the part of all mankind. This theme has been carried through in the further work of the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace on Aboriginal land rights. Many members of parliament will have seen the CCJP's issues paper 'Land Rights: A Fair Go for Aborigines', which argues persuasively for just land rights legislation and also for an educational campaign among all Australians to promote those positive steps which have already been taken in this direction in order to counteract racist campaigns against Aboriginal people. Many of Pope John Paul's statements are action oriented, reminding readers of their role in helping to build a more just society. It is appropriate to reflect on these and other prophetic statements by the Pope as Australia prepares for his visit. The Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace and Australian Catholic Relief are to be congratulated, not only on bringing these words to the attention of a wider section of-MONICA

text: Wentworth) (10.24)-I wish to use this adjournment debate to draw the House's attention to the recent death on 27 September of a very distinguished and influential Australian, Henry Richard Krygier. He was not a man for the headlines; he was, if you like, a behind the scenes organiser, or a lobbyist for his causes. He did not promote himself, but he worked ceaselessly, even relentlessly, for the preservation of a free and democratic society in Australia and in the world. Born in Warsaw in 1917, the year of the Russian Revolution, he came to this country in 1941 with his wife, Roma, from a Poland which had then been partitioned by the then allies Hitler and Stalin. He reached here via Vilna, Vladivostok, Tokyo and Shanghai, arriving shortly before Pearl Harbour. His experiences as a young man of totalitarianism-nazi and communistforged in him a physical loathing of totalitarian dictatorship of any type and also made him sensitive to what one may call pre-totalitarian sentiments. He saw the threats to democracy vividly and worked to strengthen the free at the service of life. societies. Inevitably, his first years in this country involved work in Polish circles until the Polish Government offices in Australia were closed down after the Yalta Agreement which, in efeffecfect, gave eastern and central Europe to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Richard Krygier then began to work in the wider Australian community, at first with his friend W. C. Wentworth, and later on his own. In the early 1950s he became the Australian representative of the Congress for Cultural Freedom, which was an international organisation formed in 1950 which attracted writers, artists, scientists and intellectuals generally to the defence of liberal and democratic values at a time when the full weight of Soviet propaganda was directed at undermining them and often seemed to be succeeding. In 1953 he formed an Australian Association for Cultural Freedom, an affiliate of the International Congress for Cultural Freedom. He persuaded the great lawyer, Sir John Latham, to be its first Chairman, and Sir John was followed in later years by Dr Lloyd Ross, Sir Zelman Cowen, Professor H. W. Arndt, and today Professor D. M. Armstrong as President. This Association has made significant contributions to the national debates on a range of issues affecting intellectual, artistic and cultural freedom in Australia, such questions as of censorship, academic freedom and multiculturalism before that word was commonly used. Richard Krygier had kept that collection of difficult men and women and difficult intellectuals together for more than 32 years and he was effective in that not only because of his commitment but also because his own modesty made him put the ideals of the Association above himself. No one could have been less of a prima donna. But this principal contribution to Australian cultural life was the establishment in 1956 of the magazine Quadrant. He built it up from a quarterly to a bimonthly to a monthly. It is not for me, as its current editor, to talk about its achievements, but I can say that without Richard Krygier's dedication to the magazine it would not have survived or prospered. There is much more to be said about this remarkable man. There is not time to discuss the international conferences he organised in Canberra, Malaysia and Papua New Guinea, all on the theme of building and strengthening democracy in the world. He became, through these activities, a man well known in many parts of the world. That is also evidenced in the readiness of people to pay tribute to him and his work on the occasion of Quadrant's 30th anniversary issue. These writers were from the United States, France, England and India, as well as Australia. They included his old friend Zbigniew Brzezinski, the former national security adviser to President Carter, and many editors and writers. Unhappily, Richard Krygier did not live to read these tributes. Australia has lost an extraordinary man and the world has lost an irrepressible champion of liberal and democratic values.

text: Dunkley) (10.28)-I am aware that the word 'discrimination' has been bandied about by all and sundry of late, and I rather suspect that when one hears it mentioned one tends to turn off. Nevertheless, as a city dweller, I must resurrect it one more time to point out to my State government and Territory colleagues how vitally important it is that they make every effort to administer the new funding arrangements for the soon to be defunct isolated patients travel and accommodation assistance scheme in a fair and equitable way by including in the funding support for those of us who live in cities and outlying metropolitan areas. I commend the former IPT AAS for all the positive achievements it made. More than 150,000 people were assisted by the scheme in 1985 and I am certain that they will agree with me that it was an excellent financial support for them at an important time. Even so, the scheme had some problems which I will outline briefly. For some time the Federal Government had been concerned that the scheme had been failing to meet the real needs of patients who had to travel long distances to obtain necessary health care. A working party was established in June 1985 on patient transport considerations. This comprised Commonwealth, State and Territory officials who studied the rationalisation of patient transport and the provision of assistance for interstate transport patients for speciality services and also reviewed the whole scheme. The outcome of the working party's decisions is that States and Territories will now be responsible for the administration and distribution of the funding for the people concerned. 'Responsible' is also a word that I would like to reiterate in stressing the pure meaning of the word to the States and the Territories, that is, liable to be called to account, answerable to, not to be autocratic, to be morally accountable for one's actions, to be capable of rational conduct and so forth. I urge all my State colleagues to make the right and responsible decision and support all patients in need of interstate transport and specialised care. The Government has opened the way for the States and Territories to redress this past inequitable situation and make it more efficient and effective for all those in need by providing very generous grants to the States of $1O.9m for the first six months of 1987, with a full year equivalent of $21.8m being indexed in future years. On a full year basis this represents an increase of more than 26 per cent over the $17.2m provided for the benefits that were distributed under the old scheme in 1985-86. This level of funding was increased because of the need for some capital city dwellers to travel interstate for highly specialised treatment. To give a better idea of the unfairness of the scheme in the past, let me cite a case in point in which I was recently involved. One of my constituents applied for assistance through the scheme for her son who required a heart-lung transplant. St Vincents Hospital in Sydney was the only available hospital in Australia where treatment for heart-lung transplants was carried out. To be eligible for assistance under the old scheme a patient had to reside in an isolated area, which was defined as residing more than 200 kilometres from the specialist. All areas other than the metropolitan areas of Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Adelaide and Perth were considered isolated. However, even though Frankston was more than 800 kilometres from the specialist, it was not considered isolated. The constituent had to pay for the accommodation and air fares necessary to get her son the treatment that he so urgently needed. Understandably, she was hurt, both emotionally and financially, by the regulations. I made representations on her behalf to the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), but they were not successful. They were not successful because the patient was classified as not living in an isolated area. I believe that it would show a total lack of conscience if the States and Territories did not follow through on the Federal Government's lead and make funding available for all Australians who need it, not just those from isolated country areas. The Labor Government prides itself on its many excellent policies which provide assistance for all Australians from all parts of our country.

The further functions of the Institute according to the Act, are: (b) to publish, or assist in the publication of, the results of aboriginal studies; (c) to. enc?-rage and assist co-operation amongst UniVersities, museums and other institutions concerned with Aboriginal studies; and (d) to assist universities, museums and other institutions in training research workers in fields vant to aboriginal studies. The Act goes on also to identify the function of promoting Aboriginal studies primarily by giving financial and other assistance to the carrying on of those studies under the auspices of universities, museums or other institutions, et cetera. text: Makin) (10.38)-ln the few minutes avai!able to me tonight I wish to bring to the attentIOn of the House and the Australian people a quite extraordinary commercial swindle which I have had brought to my attention by a resident of South Australia. This involves a finance organisation which lends money on mortgage. I am about to talk about not any fiy-bynight finance company but the Commonwealth Bank of Australia.

Speaker: Mr DUNCAN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: If honourable members will wait a moment, they will see just what is involved in this. Honourable members will be amazed to find the details of this as they unfold in the next few minutes. My informant in South Australia, Mr Rollings, took out a mortgage with the Commonwealth Bank in September 1963. The mortgage quite, clearly stated that the bank may, at the expiration of each 10 years during the currency of the loan, vary the rate of interest on the loan provided at the rate then charged, et cetera. In other words, for those to whom it may not be clear, this provides for 10-year rests; the interest rate could not be varied except at lO-year intervals. Quite properly, in 1973 the bank wrote and varied the interest rate from $32 per month to $36 per month-Mr MCGauran-Ha, hal

Speaker: Mr DUNCAN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Such were the interest rates of those days. On 1 September 1983 it increased the rate from 6.25 per cent to 12 per cent. So far so good; everything was in accordance with the requirements of the mortgage. Then, in August 1985 a circular letter was sent to this mortgagor, Mr Rollings, indicating that a loan service fee was to be applied. I do not need to go into whether or not that was proper and correct in law under the mortgage, because soon after a letter was sent to the mortgagor indicating that the Bank was no longer going to proceed with the loan service fee. In those circumstances the bank wrote to the mortgagor: Please accept our sincere apologies for any concern we may have caused you on receipt of the earlier notification. I must say that I was very pleased to see the Commonwealth Bank doing that, as I was one of those who complained bitterly about the ruse involved in applying a service fee instead of increasing mortgage rates, where that was possible. Mr Downer-It was a trick.

Speaker: Mr DUNCAN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: We will hear about tricks in a moment. On 10 April 1986 the Commonwealth Bank wrote to Mr Rollings indicating that it was going to increase his interest rate from 12 per cent to 12.5 per cent. It simply indicated in that letter; which I do not have time to read in full: Accordingly. the interest rate on your loan has been increased to 12.50% pa effective from the due date of the April 1986 repayment. The mortgage in this case does not provide for that; it does not allow for such increases except in the 10-year rests provided for in the mortgage. I want to know from the Commonwealth Bank how many thousands of other notices of this sort were sent out to people who may not have been as street smart as Mr Rollings. Mr Rollings is a person who keeps all of the documents provided under his mortgage and was therefore able to check back to see that he was being taken for a ride and an attempted swindle was going on. There may well be many thousands of others throughout the nation who have received these letters and have simply paid up, believing that the Bank had the right under the mortgage arrangements to claim these sorts of payments. Mr Rollings suggested to me that Ned Kelly was hanged for less than that. I think he was entirely right and the Commonwealth Bank owes the people of Australia an explanation. A response is needed from the Commonwealth Bank as to how many thousands of other people-so-called clients-throughout the nation were sent this sort of letter of demand with no basis in law for the sending of the letters.

Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Braddon) (10.43)-Over the last weekend in Tasmania the normal situation which arises in spring time has arisen again. The debate about the environment has come up again, as the Australian Heritage Commission has come out with a report saying that logging should not occur in one of the areas close to a national park area. One gets a little bit cynical about this, after a few years of noticing that the conservation movement in Tasmania always has something to hang its arguments on at this time of the year in preparation for organising students and people during the summer months. It never seems to happen at any other time of the year. It is very interesting to note that the complaint is about a pristine view from the national park, with the conservation movement complaining that it does not want to see any logging going on in a State forest area which is alongside the national park, yet it is at least six or seven kilometres away from the edge of the national park. The complaint is that it will spoil the view from the national park, even though the area which will be logged is in a State forest area. The situation is that there has to be a limit to what we will allow the conservation movement to do in regard to locking up resources in our nation. When we have the Heritage Commission saying that it would be a severe fire risk, I question whether the Heritage Commission has the same skills as the Tasmanian Forestry Commission to make that sort of judgment. Mr MCGauran-1t definitely does not.

Speaker: Mr MILES
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I agree with the honourable member that it definitely does not have the ability to make that judgment. I think it ought to restrict its comments to those which it is qualified to make and should not make those types of allegations. In 1983 a management plan was approved by the Government for the Lemon Thyme Valley. It has been accepted by the Federal Government. The spokesman for the Tasmanian conservation movement, Mr Geoff Law, says that it is now up the the Federal Government to honour its promise and stop the logging operations. Speaker: Mr OKEEFE
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Burke) (10.47)-I rise to comment upon the success to date, as observed in my electorate, of the Buy Australian campaign and to report to the House some of the responses I have been getting from shoppers in the shopping centres around my electorate. It is quite clear that people are picking up the message that Australian manufactured goods which are well designed and well marketed can compete both at home and overseas. I am pleased to see that this message is coming through to people as they are making their buying decisions. It is clear that, providing our shoppers go into shopping centres with a commitment to buy Australian, to ask for Australian made goods and to demand high quality Australian made goods, our manufacturers and producers will respond. The obligation lies upon manufacturers, retailers and producers to provide high quality goods at a competitive price and to improve upon their marketing, labelling and service. If we put all that together as a recipe, it is clear that we can mix together the blend of fewer imports, more exports and stable prices. I make the point that prices in Australia have been rising faster than wages; something which those who set the prices in Australia have to face up to. If we put those factors together, we have a recipe for success. Our economy is as finely tuned as a Finnerty guitar. I know something about those guitars. They are an excellent style and make and have to be finely tuned. An economy which has to be finely tuned depends upon the people to respond to these sorts of directions as they are laid out in the buy Australian campaign. I report to you, Madam Speaker, that people in towns such as Castlemaine, Daylesford, Ballan, Heathcote, Maldon and Kyneton, all across my electorate, are responding to the campaign. They want to support the Government's call for people to prefer to buy Australian made products. The campaign is working. I noted with some humour that in July the Melbourne Sun led with a front page headline about dollar doom. That if was when the dollar reached 66c against the American dollar. Yesterday the Melbourne Herald, which is part of the same stable, carried the headline 'Dollar healthy at 63.7c'. It has taken those economic pundits a little longer than some to learn that the devaluation of the Australian dollar is not a message of doom for our economy but the recipe by which our manufacturers are suddenly realising that they are back in the market-place again. They are realising that they can compete, that imports are now too dear and that consumers are ready to show the preference for Australian made products for which we are all looking. This will result in the turn-around in the economy that we all want to see. I commend the Treasurer ( Mr Keating) and the Government for having stuck to their guns and adhered to their policy. It is clear in my electorate that the people both understand it and are supporting it. If I were a manufacturer of Australian made products, I would be concentrating on the right price, high quality and good service. I know that that would be a recipe for success.

Speaker: Mr HICKS
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Riverina-Darling) (l0.52)-Recently I attended the opening of extensions to the Burke Ward Primary School at Broken Hill. The school's colours are red and black and the motto is 'Strive with Honour'. The school has been in existence for nearly a century and there would be few schools that have a tradition such as that of the Burke Ward school. I speak from experience because my grandparents attended the school, as did my parents. My wife was captain of the school at one stage and my children attended the school. I am very proud of the school. The extensions were opened by Rod Cavalier, the Minister for Education of New South Wales. Although he is not of the same political persuasion as myself, I have a great deal of respect for him. In the past he has taken a great deal of care and notice of the people in western New South Wales-in the bush, as we call it-who have particular problems. He has made sure that the schools in that area are staffed by good teachers. He has ensured also that the smaller bush schools that may have closed have not closed. These schools have attended to the education of the children in the area and, in common with most bush schools, they remain the centre of the community in the areas of which I am speaking. The Burke Ward school is noted for its discipline, the standard of education and the way in which the children who attend it behave. It is noted for its style of teaching. It has a fife band, which has been in existence since the school opened. The people of Broken Hill are proud of the band, which wins many awards both in New South Wales and in South Australia. In the past fortnight the Central School has celebrated its centenary. It has shifted location in the past few years, but it marks a century of education in Broken Hill. That is important because, as was stated at the opening of the extensions at the Burke Ward school and at the centenary celebrations of the Central School, Broken Hill has many teachers who uphold the traditions of teaching in New South Wales. When younger teachers come to the area, they teach them the ropes. Teachers colleges are more or less kindergartens for future teachers, and when young teachers come to Broken Hill there are great educators who remove the rough edges from them and provide a real education for those who are to teach in Broken Hill. I suppose that my speech is designed to pay tribute to the Burke Ward primary school and the Central School in Broken Hill as well as the high schools-Broken Hill High and Willyama High-and the other primary schools to which I have not yet referred, the North Primary School, the Railway Town Primary School, and the Alma Primary School. There are many schools in Broken Hill, including private schools, and they all provide an education for the young children of the area, something which is especially important for those in isolated areas. I pay tribute to those schools and to their educators who have done so much for Broken Hill, for the State of New South Wales and for the people of Australia in educating those young people who went on to become giants in the mining industry, in areas of science and in just about every following that can be undertaken in Australia. I am sure all honourable members would join me in paying tribute to the educators of Broken Hill.

Speaker: Mr TICKNER
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: Hughes) (10.55)-Tonight I draw the attention of the House to what I consider to be a potential very serious threat to public health. That threat is posed by a substance commonly referred to as smokeless tobacco. I first had my concerns alerted to this substance by an organisation called ASH Australia, which is Action on Smoking and Health. This organisation was formed by the National Heart Foundation of Australia and a number of other leading Australian authorities on public health which are joining together to campaign against the use of tobacco in society and to alert Australians to the fact that some 16,000 of our number die each year as a result of diseases directly attributable to the use of tobacco. However, a new product is coming on the market in Australia which has only comparatively recently become available. Smokeless tobacco has sometimes been referred to as snuff and sometimes as chewing tobacco but whatever form it comes in it is, according to all the available evidence, as dangerous to public health as is smoking cigarettes in the most commonly used form. The smokeless tobacco that I have seen is promoted in Australia by W.D. and H.O. Wills (Australia) Ltd. It is commonly referred to by the product name of Skoal Bandits and is in the form of a little tea bag of tobacco which is placed between the lip and the gum. The tobacco is leached from the tea bag substance into the blood stream. Prolonged usage can cause cancer. I emphasise that I am not attempting to bash tobacco users. I know there are members in the chamber tonight who fall into that category. But whether or not we are users of tobacco we would all agree that if we can discourage young kids from using this substance and minimise its use in society it will be a better society. The information I have is that the importation of smokeless tobacco has increased three-fold in the last three years and that there is a decided push to increase the sale of this product in coming years. A prominent representative of the American tobacco companies is in Australia at the moment to promote the use of this substance. It is not just my opinion that the use of this tobacco constitutes a serious risk to public health. The leading British medical magazinethe Lancet-has also chronicled the record of this substance, as has the World Health Organisation and the New England Journal of Medicine from the United States of America. The marketing practices of tobacco companies in the United States used every trick in the book, including utilising sporting heroes and country and western singers, in order to promote the product. The National Health and Medical Research Council has, to the best of my knowledge, put forward a proposal that the product be placed on the list of prohibited imports into Australia. I understand there has been some communication with the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce but as yet the Government has not made a final decision on this matter. I stress that I am not a wowser, but I sincerely believe that if the Government acts on this problem now we can avoid a major public health problem which could cause a tremendous amount of cost to our country and to young Australians ..

text: Robertson-Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment) (1I.OO)-Earlier the honourable member for Braddon ( Mr Miles) mentioned the Lemon Thyme Forest, which I presume is in his electorate. Mr Miles-No, it is in the Lyons electorate.

Speaker: Mr COHEN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: It is in a region in which he is interested. He made some reference to comments of the Australian Heritage Commission that there should be no logging in the Lemon Thyme Forest because the area could be viewed from the Cradle Mountain National Park, which is part of a World Heritage area, and logging would spoil the pristine view from that important and internationally famous park. I would like to deal with a number of issues raised by the honourable member for Braddon. I refer first of all to the Australian Heritage Commission. That body is my responsibility. I think he said that he was referring to the comments of the Heritage Commission as if it were the conservation movement. Mr Miles-No, I was not saying that.

Speaker: Mr COHEN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: I misunderstood what the honourable member said. Of course, the Heritage Commission is not part of the conservation movement; it is a government organisation and its responsibilities are to compile the National Estate Register and to monitor what goes on in that regard. Of course, it also advises the Government on actions it should take. The matter raised by the honourable member has been of considerable concern to me and has been a part of a heritage review which we have just about completed. I refer to the misunderstanding that has occurred in the minds of many people about what listing on the National Estate register means. There is a misunderstanding on the part of loggers, developers and people in State and local government that listing on the register means that nothing can happen in an area, that it is a no-go area that must remain untouched, whether it be a built environment or a natural environment. That misunderstanding often arises as a result of ignorance. The conservation movement has been guilty-I am not sure whether through ignorance or deliberately-of creating the impression that listing on the National Estate Register means that an area cannot be touched. The honourable member quite rightly said that the Federal Government had said in its agreement with the Tasmanian Government that it would strive to protect National Estate values. It did not mean and has never meant by that that no action could take place in a National Estate area. If that were the case, nothing would ever happen in any of the 7,000 areas listed on the National Estate Register. That is not the case. The Commonwealth Government requires that when some action is proposed concerning a particular site or area on the Register the Minister must take note of that action and ensure that if possible its National Estate values are protected. It should try to avoid any action which would in any way despoil the area. As very often happens in the case of a building, for example, the Minister, in this case me, and the Government might well consider that and make a decision that it should proceed, despite the fact that it might damage the area's Estate values. We will try not to do that but in some cases it is unavoidable.

Title: ADJOURNMENT

Speaker: Mr COHEN
Title: ADJOURNMENT
text: The Government is in the process of setting up a committee which will work with the Tasmanian Government to ensure that, in the woodchip agreements which we are working out with that Government, the National Estate values of those areas, if humanly possible, will be fully protected. The honourable member raised the case of whether there should be logging in the State forest because it can be seen from the World Heritage area of the Cradle Mountain National Park. I have some sympathy with that view but I also understand the view that the honourable member put forward that there is a limit to how many buffers one can have. We have a national park and then a buffer for the national park and then a buffer for the buffer. It goes on forever. Concerning the Lemon Thyme, the conservation movement has been concerned that logging there could be viewed from the World Heritage area and would despoil its pristine values. To the best of my knowledge-I was not able to get details on this matter at such short notice-that matter will be looked at by the committee. That committee is balanced. People on that committee will represent the forestry and logging interests of Tasmania-employers and employeesand will also have conservationists and independent people on it. The honourable member will find it to be a committee whose judgments we can trust. I just say to people at this stage not to panic. Tasmanians have a tendency at times to go off the air when some of these issues are mentioned. I believe that this matter can be satisfactorily resolved. I will certainly take note of the honourable member's comments and see that they are referred to the appropriate authorities.
